So what's good about this game? Well let Swerve tell you! This is going to be long as hell since I used to play the orginal a crap ton 3 years ago! So gather round children! Grab a seat and listen to the great story I am about to tell!

Diplomacy:

The game provides a pretty solid diplomacy system that fits in very well with the backstory of the game. This means that it's harder to ally with Vasari rebels when you're a Vasari loyalist, unless you already premade the teams ofc. The computer or player can give you missions, if you choose to do them will improve your relations with them. Eventually if they like you enough they ask for peace treaties, powerful pacts (These buff both of your factions), trade agreements, ect. Even though diplomacy is useful in a game, it's not the core aspect of this game, you shouldn't buy it expecting it to be a game like Anno 1404 where war is only an option.
Your goal is to kill everyone, not to make peace with them.

TL;DR
Overall it's a nice mechanic, it fits with the story, highly dynamic, and very diverse, but not the main focus of the game.

Combat:

Personally, I think the combat is very simple.
You have your ship types:

reviewText:
This is by far my favorite strategy game.

For those of you who are new to Sins it will be a bit of a challenge figuring out how to play the game but trust me put the time in and it pays off. The difficulty of the game can be tweaked to suit anybody's needs, wether your'e looking for a quick 1 on 1 match against an easy opponent or an 8 player free for all against ruthless AI, or compete against real human beings online.  Be warned though, matches can last for hours and hours, this can be a good or bad point depending on your play style.  Visuals are great, so much satisfaction to be had in zooming all the way in on your massive fleets and watching them demolish your rivals empire in flurries of lasers, and explosions.

Long story short, if your'e into games like Total War, Glactic Civilizations, Supreme Commander then your'e definately going to want to pick this up.  40$ is a little steep though so look for it to go on sale, I was able to pick it up for 8$.

reviewText: Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion is one of the best Strategy Games i know and maybe the best Galactic Strategy Game. Lets begin with the Gameplay. You can choose between 3 Races: TEC (Trader Emergency Coalition) they are human, The Advent was originally a desert religious cult that mastered psychic powers and The Vasari they are the only alien race in the game. A new feature: For every race (TEC,Advent,Vasari) you can choose between Loyalists and Rebels both of them have their own advantages and abilities. You have many possibilities to start a game (defensive, offensive or aggressive) but to win at the end you have to attack the other empire (other players or KI). The intelligence of the KI is pretty well and if you play on a higher difficulty like unfair its really hard to win the game especially if you play agains more than one player for example 5 or even more. (10 players max.) The graphics are really nice and the galaxy with all its stars solar systems and planets looks just awsome. Only if you zoom really close to the planets you will see that their surface is fashioned a little bit boring. But all ships, frigats, star bases and structures look nice and really realistic. One of the coolest features in this game are the Titans the biggest ships you can build. Every player can only have one Titan at the same time because theyre really strong especially as support if you attack with more capital ships and a fleet. Only a full developed star base can fight against this strong ship. You can play in small solar systems with 9 planets or you can choose the biggest map: a galaxy with five solar systems and about 150 planets. Thats really big and you will need a long time to discover the whole galaxy with all its secrets and resources. Resources a one of the most important things in the game you can earn: credits (from: taxes, war and allies) metal (mainly from extractors but also from allies and war) crystal (mainly from extractors but also from allies and war). As soon as you have enough recources, planets and a few defensive structures you can start to discover the galaxy and to build your fleet with many little ships, capital ships and you big Titan. Then you can attack other empires to get their planets because for a big empire you need much space. But maybe the will attack you before you you are ready and thats the difficulty with this game: YOU NEVER KNOW WHAT HAPPENS NEXT! Thats what makes this game so interesting. Lets come to an end: This game is worth buying! You need to invest time but once you have understood everything the fun begins and you can start building many empires.\nI hope i could help you. :)

reviewText:
TL:DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a massive real-time strategy game developed by Ironclad Games and published by Stardock Entertainment. It is the third standalone expansion in the popular Sins of a Solar Empire line of games and stands as testament to why this genre can only work with the PC Platform. Although the game is classified as an RTS, it does feature a lot of 4X (Civilization type) elements which the developers are calling the 'RT4X' genre.

PLOT (No Spoilers):The player takes control of a space faring civilization whose sole objective is to be the most dominant force in the Galaxy. Achieve this either through military force, diplomatic means or economic superiority. Lead your civilization from a small single planet colony into a vast interplanetary empire spanning multiple worlds and multiple star systems.

PROS:+ Epic in scale (The player can choose to either play in one solar system only, or expand their empire to other solar systems if the map permits)
+ Massive space combat and intense fleet engagements
+ Beautiful Graphics and Visuals
+ Good ship and space station variety
+ Ship and space station customization and upgrades
+ Complex and solid core gameplay
+ Simple and easy to manage Empire Tech Tree
+ Incorporates the features of the previous expansions without forcing you to buy them
+ High replayability
+ Seamless Zoom Function (Marvel at your fleet or the intense ship on ship combat)
+ Playable even with some lower end computers
+ Modding potential (Example: See Star Trek 3 Armada mod)

CONS:- No Campaign mode and even if there was...(see below)
- Story is negligible
- Steep learning curve
- Capital/Titan Ships and Space stations have no hardpoints (see Star Wars: Empire at War space combat)
- Only three main factions to play (although there are 6 sub-factions)
- Stardock Account Management

CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME but NOT FOR EVERYONE. If you're the type of gamer who's really into real-time strategy or 4X games and have a lot of free time to burn, then this game would be great.

WORTH IT?:GOOD BUY and HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for Space, Sci-Fi, RTS and 4X fans.

FINAL NOTES:It's massive in scale with dozens of ships clashing in some of the most epic space warfare I have ever seen. Outside of combat, it has a good and complex empire management system akin to the 4X genre. The game also runs surprisingly well with the last generation computer systems since its game engine still only need the system requirements back in 2008 when it was first released.

reviewText: Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is one of the most versatile space based RTS games produced; the vanilla game offers three distinct factions and each of those has a sub faction you can choose; loyalist or rebels, each with different tech and construction options. The research trees are fairly comprehensive and cover everything from civilian, military, diplomatic and defence branches each with 30-40 techs in each branch. Therefore there can be different strategies each playthrough to some extent. But the combat is fairly satisfying as well as visually pleasing but the real beauty of Sins is the vast repository of mods available for it on sites like ModDB - Sins of a Galactic Empire (Star Wars), Star Trek Armada 3 are probably two of the most comprehensive you could check out, but there are many more. Therefore as well as the great base game you also have access to whatever particular science fiction genre you want to simulate with the solid game engine. What I would suggest for those familiar with them are programs like large address aware; but more for the mods as opposed to the base game as they tend to crank up the population capacity of ships compared to vanilla. (Due to engine constraints it only utilises the old school 4gb of ram limitation even if you have 16gb; LAA or similar will remedy this problem and allow for late game battles on a massive scale.)

reviewText:
Epic space strategy at its best! Sins polished game engine allows seamless navigation from the micro managment of your individual planetary systems & military units all the way out to the full solar system view allowing large scale tactical management.

At close range, all galactic elements as well as the ship & stations have very high level of graphic detail; they look fantastic! When you zoom out this detail is replaced with a clear tactical overlay making it easy to transition between tasks, all intuitively done with the mouse scroll wheel & pointer location. UI is low frills, but very functional.

A.I. is also well designed, smart & strong! If you are not quick & know your strategy, at harder difficulties, they will give you a real battle for your survival! Further challenges can be found in the achievements, which challenge you to only research one tech tree or not to build a type of ship. These mix up the gameplay & I enjoyed trying to get these ones. I'm still hunting for the elusive Space Ponies! :)

DLCs so far have been relatively small feature enhancements, but all worthwhile grabbing as they add a few more new things to the Sins universe. There are also some great total conversion mods (& other mods) out there to try, like one of my favs, the Star Wars total conversion mod called Sins of a Galactic Empire. Worth checking out.

Sins pretty much has it all from unique alien factions, diplomacy & extensive tech trees to missions & trading. Also population, battle & resource management & massive planetary sieges involving hundreds of ships.

The shear scale means games can go for days! Epic game!

reviewText:
A truly wonderful space based RTS. The 3 races play very differently from one another and the sub-factions are distinct enough to make you change your style depending on whether you're the Loyalists or Rebels.

The game's pace can be easily adjusted in the pregame options to suit your skill and the AI does a good job of building counters to your units (e.g. you build long range, AI builds corvettes). Having said that, the AI has a greater emphasis on the Artifical as opposed to Intelligence as it essentially attempts to win through attrition.

But such AI strategies are to be expected and, in my opinion, lead to some pretty epic battles. Build a starbase on a key chokepoint and station a fleet there to try and hold the line, if you're playing Hard or higher the AI will be charging your line in no time with capital ships, frigates, corvettes, cruisers and even titans.

The game is also extremely moddable. If you can read this review you can mod a good portion of Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion. There are also tonnes of mods already created (Halo, Star Wars, Star Trek, etc.).

Finally, while the game does not have a campaign I personally feel this is no loss. Honestly ask yourself, Would I play the campaign more than three times?" Probably not unless there was some meaningful reward (which would be difficult to work into the game). As a result
date: the omission of a four to eight hour campaign is no big loss.\n\nI could go on and on but I'm worried you'll keep reading when you should just go get the game already!"

reviewText:
tl;dr: This is good game. Cheap for what you get, lots of mods. Good optimization, much pretty. Music nice, gameplay nice, must play for space RTS fans.

Sins of a Solar Empire is a space RTS with no campaign, but endless replayability. Every game, the universe that the game is played in is randomized, or selected from a premade map (which offer specific challenges to make the game more interesting). There can be many stars in one universe, and each star can have very few or very many planets, asteroids, wormholes, etc.

The game offers a very nice blend of combat, research, and dimplomacy. But research really trumps everything, which leads into one of Sins' flaws... the difficulty curve. This game will kick your ♥♥♥ if you are a newcomer to the RTS genre, and even if you are a veteran, you will find a good challenge. This game is not for the easily frustrated, because going against AI, or other players, can really pump up the blood pressure sometimes.

The game itself runs very well for my system. I'm running it on an AMD FX 6300 Processor, NvidiaGTX 660, with 8 GB of RAM, and it runs perfectly fine. It is very well optimized and looks beautiful. The backgrounds of space look phenomenal and the ships look pretty good too. Watching the space battles can be so nice to look at that you forget to make sure they are actually doing alright.

Anyway, This game is worth the $40, but I would also cash in for the DLC, because they are very good for the price. The modding potential for this game is amazing as well. If you ever get bored of the basic game, you can just browse the giant selection of quality mods on Moddb. If there is a popular movie/TV/game/book series taking place in space, there is a good possibility that there is a well made mod already created, or being crafted of it.

Thanks for reading, if you got this far, and I hope this review helps, although the fact that there are already 1,000's of positive reviews made for this game should be a clear indication of the quality of Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion.

reviewText: If you've never experienced Sins of a Solar Empire before, you'll find no better entry point than Rebellion. But if Rebellion commits any sins of its own, it's in the 37$ price tag, which seems excessive for an expansion that will almost certainly strike its loyal fans as little more than a meaty content patch.Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion adds some nice features to a great, proven winner of a game. Those features are nice, but as nice as they are, I couldn't really see myself running out and throwing down nearly forty bucks for this standalone expansion if I already owned the original Sins, to say nothing of its expansion packs.But on the other hand, Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is an outstanding and unique real-time strategy game that offers a welcome, slower alternative to StarCraft 2's intense pacing. As a life-long fan of sci-fi space battles, I simply can't help but strongly recommend it.The important part here is that Sins of a Solar Empire still delivers a very unique kind of strategy game, and Rebellion doesn't screw with that; instead, it makes that base game substantially smoother and more interesting.

reviewText:
The following describes my experience every time I play this game.

The first scenario.

I take my sweet time, playing turtly and expanding slowly, mainly because I'm still fresh from Endless Space and rapid expansion is dangerous, in my mind. I fully upgrade every single world until I can make my empire like a house, except I paint each indavidual brick before I lay it, polish it, and make it amazing. A slow process.

Then the enemy fleet arrives, bristling with LRM frigates and siege engines, capitol ships all over the damn place, shredding my meager defenses while I scramble to make some kind of response fleet. I lose in minutes when this happens. Hours of work, gone in seconds.

The second scenario.

I make one capitol ship right off, usually the one with colonization capability, and build a fleet to defend it before I even start growing. From there, I expand. The colonization fleet dives into the universe and takes everything not bolted down, planting my flag in every piece of dirt they can find. While this is happening, I'm researching like a madman. Everything from the civilian tree goes first, mainly mining and expansion assistance. I'm able to colonize any world by about minute fifteen, and do so with abandon.

While the colonization fleet is away, I build up the battle fleet. More capitol ships, hundreds of frigates and cruisers, and a Titan being build in the corner of my home gravity well. My scouts find pirates, enemy players/AI, and all number of worlds. I take everything I can get my hands on and build up more gauss cannons than I can count. If anyone pokes around my systems, they don't leave alive.

Finally, I run into worlds that I can't take with my small colonization fleet. So I pull them back. The enemy mounts an assault, thinking me weak. I let them come, break their backs on my frontier worlds, cracking their armor on my defenses.

Then the battle fleet arrives.

I destroy their assault force in moments, my capitol ships shredding anything in their path, Titan mysteriously AWOL, and drive them back four systems or more before they manage to scramble up a defense. When they do, my Titan and its auxilery fleet arrive...behind them. On a world where they have few defenders, she enters the fray, and ignores the first three worlds completely. Her goal is the capitol. In a desperate attempt to keep their forces strong enough to fight me, the enemy pulls everyone back to the capitol system, and mounts their last stand.

I leave no survivors.



This game is amazing. A little slow, as it usually takes me an hour just to get comfortable with my standing, but oh so very addicting. The above situations happen often, rather than once or twice in a while, and though it does take a long time to build up your fleet, seeing it warp in out of nowhere is a warming experience I've yet to feel elsewhere. Endless space scratched the itch to rule an empire. This scratched my itch to conquer the galaxy.

I'm not one for numbers, but this one gets an 11/10. Best played with friends and open alliances, over coms where you can covertly talk to each other. The envoys let you spy on 'allies' easily, and the diplomacy is enough to play the sides until you emerge on top. I've nearly lost friends for the plays I make here, feinting aggression to one faction when really I'd had envoys with them the whole time, and that battle fleet I'd been prepping was for my early game 'ally' that was a little too demanding with my resources.

Love at first conquest.

reviewText:
In the grim darkness of the 41st millenium, there is only war. Mankind fights an endless - no wait sorry, that's a different game. It's not even an original video game, it was based on a tabletop game. This is a completely different game.

Thousands of years in the future, the ways of war have been forgotten (oh my god, this is literally the exact opposite of 40k, how did I get those two mixed up, what'm I like?) and an era of peace and prosperity has been ushered in for mankind.

Then the aliens came. Fleeing from a terror they know nothing about, they laid waste to the outer worlds and took humanity completely by surprise.

Then, because when things go wrong they go really wrong, a faction of exiled psionics returned after their long exodus calling themselves the Advent, also laying waste to the outer worlds. Man, the outer worlds really suck. If I lived in space, I'd stay the hell away from outer worlds of any kind. They're always full of criminals or the first to be hit by an invasion or whatever, always live near the centre of a space empire. Remember the Star Wars prequels? Actually, don't remember the Star Wars prequels, they were awful. But the Outer Rim sucked in those too. Well everything sucked, but the Outer Rim especially.

Anyway, the traders united to form the TEC, or Traders' Emergency Coalition, to fight off the other two armies and none of this is relevant at all. Seriously.

Wait, let me check... Nope, definitely irrelevant. I can't find a campaign mode anywhere. Why would they do that? Who does that!? Who writes a backstory and then gives no story!?

Well alright then. It's a space RTS. Instead of soldiers, you blow up spaceships. You conquer planets. You play as one of the three factions mentioned above, as either Loyalist or Rebel. In many matches, this is all to get the resources for building a really big spaceship called a Titan, and those are awesome. They've got great abilities. Vasari (aliens) Loyalists get a Titan that can eat spaceships. And Advent Rebels get a Titan that can heal itself as your other ships are blown up. The TEC just get boring grey stuff for boring grey humans.

A single match can last anywhere from a few hours to a week. Actually, if it lasts for a few hours, that's because someone has ragequit.

The final verdict is, it's a unique and fun RTS about blowing up spaceships, which is pretty much every sci-fi fan's dream. It's not without bugs or cheating AI, but it's definitely worth buying if you want a decent game to play with friends.

reviewText:
This is a niche game. You have to love RTS titles to begin with in order to get all you can out of this game. That being said, this may be the greatest RTS game ever created.

Pro:

- Intricate, detailed gameplay that allows for nearly infinite strategies, compounded by six readily distinguishable classes, each with easily understood strengths and weaknesses.

- Gorgeous gameplay, small battles feel like a desperate struggle, large battles feel like an epic contest of ultimate power, and all planet/star models are meticulously rendered into sprawling heaps of sublimity.

- Early/Mid/Late game all allow for new strategy to be applied, letting the player modify their tactics to better meet the assuredly unexpected challenges they face.

- In-Game map creator allows for pretty much any map style the player could ever want.

- Solid multiplayer mode, far less lag than would be expected for a game of this sheer magnitude.

- Player interface is smooth and allows at-hand modification for hotkeys, etc.

- Extremely advanced AI, on harder difficulties your robot opponents will be very difficult to defeat.

Con:

- The learning curve is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ brick wall. At least two or three hours of tutorial + practice are required before you stand a chance of beating even the Easy AI.

- Micromanaging is a must, although I love it, assigning keybindings for every possible ability and advancement can be tedious, and is unfortunately a must for high-end competitive play. Not much is required for basic play, but for some, dealing with planetary income/resource/optimization issues will be a chore.

- This game is an enourmous time investment, I've played matches that lasted over twelve hours. The shortest match I've ever played was probably about two hours.

- No campaign mode. I hate to even say it, but if this game had one, it would shine brighter than a pulsar.

Essentially, if you like RTS games, strategy games in general, or mentally challenging games in more general still, you will love this. I've spent hundreds of hours (I bought and played independently before buying on steam for multiplayer reasons) and none of them I feel have been wasted. I love this game, and I truly believe it is the best RTS game ever made, despite what minor (to me) flaws it may have.

The game worth the time? Yes
The game worth the £29.99? Maybe as I am not sure how much of an RTS person you are, and I am not an RTS person much, but I enjoy this.

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText:
Space Strategy enthusiasts rejoice: real-time strategy meets 4X rules in a seamlessly zoomable universe that hasn't looked or felt this polished since the original Homeworld game. Marketed as a stand-alone expansion for Sins of a Solar Empire, Rebellion basically sums up every mechanic introduced in every expansion to date - fight off pirates and opposing empires, establish trade routes, colonize or raise every planet in your solar system... and beyond. It has the same addictiveness as Civilization, in that you feel like you're playing a board game in which your faction fights to rule the universe using various tools or domination and manipulation, every match a new iteration in the array of destinies you can forge. On top of that, the space battles are impressive in both scale and effects: tons of freaking laser beams, rockets and machine gun fire keep you at the edge of your seat when a few hundred ships in your fleet meet a few hundred of your opponents' craft and clash in a display of fireworks that is so visceral and pretty it blows your brains out and leaves you slack jawed at the display of awesomeness.

BUY it if you:
-Enjoy RTS games and civ builders alike.
-Want to engage in large-scale space battles with budget hardware (the game's zoom function works like a miracle, letting you join in on epic skirmishes or zoom out to manage your home planet in the blink of an eye).
-Always wanted to recreate the Dominion assault on Deep Space Nine or some other notoriously nerdy science fiction scene you're almost embarassed you enjoy so much.

DO NOT BUY it if you:
-Hate the pacing of RTS games (learning hotkeys, developing effective build orders and being fast in setting your bases is essential to mastering Sins of a Solar Empire, and if you need time to think things through, you might be better off waiting for Civilization: Beyond Earth for your 4X fix).
-Expect a campaign or any kind of predesigned narrative - Rebellion has none.

reviewText:
Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a 4X real-time strategy from Stardock Entertainment, the few of its kind. This game is a standalone expansion of the previous game Sins of a Solar Empire: Trinity.

Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion gameplay is exactly the same as the previous game but expanded in some ways. Each faction in Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion has been splitted into two, a loyalist faction and a rebel faction, each with their own unique background story and traits. Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion also introduce new mighty unit called Titan. Titan is unique with each faction. There is also smaller new ship, the corvette unit which is also unique with each faction. This add new elements of strategy and gameplay to the game. Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion also offer two new DLC, one of them contains new feature, the random events, which will affect your gameplay much.

Graphics of Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion has also been improved. Weapons effect, ships boosters and many other space environment graphics are all enhanced, making the big space battles even more epic than ever. Ships and planets also have better texture now. The game still runs optimized despite all enhanced graphics but still unable to utilize more than 2GB of RAM. When the game run out of memory, most of the time it will crash, but it rarely happen unless you're using 3rd party modification.

There are some mods that making Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion even more fun and interesting, like the Star Trek Armada, changing the whole game universe into Star Trek Universe, Federations, Klingons and all.

Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is great standalone expansion pack. Great addition to Sins of a Solar Empire fans. I recommend this.

Rating 9/10

reviewText:
Too ruggedly professional to die, 2008 sleeper hit Sins of a Solar Empire has returned. Titled Rebellion, this third expansion comes in a new, expandalone format, and adds just about everything except actual rebellion. Silly developers!

Sins has aged well, partly because its only competitor, Sword of the Stars II, flopped harder than a snake slipping off a diving board, but also because its appeal is still intact. As you develop your empire, swinging from planet to planet, tumbling down the tech tree, stringing together fleets and levelling up your capital ships, the game simply gives you a bit too much to think about.

It’s uncanny. As a beginner, you’ll have your hands (and head) full developing trade routes and continuing the electric push of your culture across the solar system, perhaps with one eye on your prize fleet, making sure it’s still winning some 20-minute pitched battle. But experts will be kept just as busy micromanaging the powers on individual ships, perhaps leaping home to oversee the construction of a Maginot Line-like array of turrets, before snapping up the diplomacy menu to offer a job, a ceasefire, a demand, then back to the fight.

Sins’ sweet spot is that it always threatens to overwhelm, but rarely does. This isn’t the riptide real-time strategy of StarCraft II. It’s more sedate than that. But the game simply has so much going on, its every element rewarding not just attention but obsession, that you’re able to sink into it like a hot bath. Want to fling armadas around as if they were plastic toys? You’ll have a great time. Want to orchestrate your fleets like an interplanetary Rommel? You’ll see the rewards instantly.

Which brings us to what Rebellion adds. Perhaps most notably, it still doesn’t add a singleplayer campaign, leaving you to fool around either online or in the excellently robust skirmish mode. Which is fine. There’s also a whole new suite of tutorials, which prepare you for everything – except how to deal with this much content.

Sins’ three relatively asymmetrical races have been further rent into Rebel and Loyalist variants, each of which holds a new teasing selection of powerful abilities and a unique Titan. We’ll get to those. Loyalist TEC, for example, are a turtle’s dream, with one tech that increases experience gained fighting in their own space and another that lowers the cost of the horrible Novalith Cannon (which lets them slam-dunk nukes into distant gravity wells). Meanwhile, the nomadic Vasari Loyalists gain the power to summon NPC vagabonds and devour planets like so many Mars Bars.

There are new corvettes and capital ships for each faction, too, but the Titans are the stars of the show. Monstrously expensive and perfectly suited to a long-form game like Sins, it’s likely the fiercest fighting these behemoths will see will be attacks by wary players on their sprawling dockyard before they’re completed.

As with everything else in the game, however, they strike a thoughtful balance. Completing a Titan is by no means a ‘win’ button, but the automated report that another player has finished one still instils a gentle dread.

Outside of the lack of a singleplayer campaign, about the only criticism that could be levelled at Rebellion is that it’s not much of a looker anymore. But you know what? When you jump some 50 ships on top of an enemy fleet, announcing your presence in a flutter of missiles and hot burps of laser fire, you just can’t tear your eyes away.

reviewText:
I, personally, enjoy this game, and if you are into space combat games at all, you will enjoy Sins of a Solar Empire. The original game was fantastic, and with Rebellion, comes even more fun! Take command of one of three factions, and choose whether you are a Loyalist or a Rebel. Each faction has their own backstory and reasons for why they are fighting, and the sins they are paying for.

The technology trees have been expanded ever so slightly, and the tech from before has been reworked. Perhaps you want to upgrade how effecient your mining is or maybe you want to start broadcasting how amazing your civilization is across space. Choose whether you want to upgrade your ships' weaponry or armor, to field more variations or ships, or build your defenses.

Speaking of ships, they have added in two new classifications: the Corvette and the Titan. The Corvette is a fast little attack ship, sporting a few weapons, and a debilitating effect. They take only a research upgrade to start producing. And then comes the Titan. These behemoths take several research upgrades, not-to-mention an arm and a leg worth of resources to start producing. You can only field one at a time, but these monsters are devastating.

Each faction has one new capital ship as well, which can be of varying use in certain aspects of the game. The original five capital ships have been revamped, with their abilities being reworked and revamped. Not everything has been changed, but a few tweaks have been made, to make sure they are still viable and fun to use.

This is the only part that I still have a problem with: the planetary upgrades. Planets can be upgraded in a handful of different areas, and different types of planets can receive a different number of upgrades, up to a maximum of four. These upgrades can allow a larger planetary population or increasing the number of tactical (defensive structures and the like) or logistical (research platforms, broadcasting stations, shipyards). It could increase the health of the planet (and thus how much damage it can take from enemy bombardment), or explore the planet. This could lead to planetary anomalies that could be beneficial or penalize the planet, or even discover a long-lost artifact, which would have beneficial affects for your empire as a whole. The reason I have a problem with this is because it is too streamlined. Once a planet is upgraded, there is no reason to keep coming back to it, unless it is being attack.

That being said, do I recommend the game? Yes. Absolutely. Gameplay is almost never stale, as the game changes every time you start it again. Anyone that enjoys the aspect of large naval space engagements would positively love Sins of a Solar Empire. And with this 75% off deal going on for this weekend, I would jump at the opportunity.

reviewText: I still consider this game from Stardock to be one of, if not the best of the 4X space genre! I started with the original game and have purchased each of it's successors and, or DLC's. I have never felt let down in any game from this gaming series. I've always enjoyed playing each and everyone of the releases. Many, many games have brought themselves into this 4X space genre and I've tried out many demos from the competition. I've also purchased many other games in this genre, yet to date none have compared to Sins of a Solar Empire, in my humble opinion. The gameplay is smooth and extremely beautiful, even when you zoom in as close as you can. And have literally hundreds to thousands of ships in the grips of warfare (including the AI or enemy player's ships). I highly recommend that you purchase the DLC, especially for this release. Because it brings a lot more options and most importantly; Tons mo' fun to the table.\n\nThere's also a lot of depth in this game, if you so choose to dig deeper. From planetary upgrades, fleet upgrades, starbases and the awe inspiring Titan Class. There's always something to do and MM is easily tamed if that's your play style, and the game moves fast or slow. You decide -- there are so many options before dropping into battle as to what could possibly happen. Don't like pirates? Fine, simply disable them or better yet choose a faction that harnesses the pirates to do your bidding. Don't like playing with diplomatic measures influencing the game? You can disable or bend these options to your will as well. Truly, the options are endless. This game gives you so much control, whether it be through the options menu and, or the faction you choose to play as. I could go on, but I think you have a firm grip on the gist of what I'm spraying. Not to mention the fact I've babbled on and this review is long enough as is.

reviewText:
This game is an interesting blend of 4X and RTS, on one hand you have to capture chokepoint planets and deny resources to your opponent all the while making careful decisions about which research to go into next, on the other hand you have to micromanage unit abilities in order to win any sort of competitive combat.

The learning curve for this game is indeed high if only because which race variant you play impacts the strategies you can effectively use.

Thankfully there are many good articles online to help you understand the concepts and advanced strategies possible in this game.

For lovers of RTS, this game is a must. The graphics are beautiful, the AI punishing, and the multiplayer grueling.
Expect competition.        Expect to be challenged.

ENVOY RATED: 9/10

reviewText:
Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a sequel of sorts for Sins of a Solar Empire. Rebellion adds many things to the game, but its primary additions are the Titans, which are massive Mothershipesque monstrosities which dwarf the capital ships.

There are still the three primary factions: Vasari, TEC, Advent. This game, however, splits those factions into Loyalist and Rebel factions that the player can choose. These factions diversify the choices and play styles of the factions. The Vasari are still, in general, very war and destruction focused (you get cool gravely voices and get to strip planets). The TEC are still pretty trade and defense focused. The Advent are still rather culture focused. The factions do add a little difference to the play style.

The primary reason to play this game is the feeling of power as you conquer planets and then galaxies. The game is very long with even a one galaxy game taking hours. It is loads of fun in multiplayer, but you might find that you have to dedicate an entire weekend to a good multi-galaxy 3-5 player game. My and my buds in college did this more often than we probably should have!

The story for this game is essentially the context of the races. Make up your own story! Are you the TEC turned aggressive? Do you want to be constantly quoting Join the Unity" or "I am the Unity's Servant" with your friends? Play the Advent and be annoying! Are you the Vasari who have decided to like trade and culture (if so
date: you're playing them wrong. Play the advent). DO YOU WANT TO CONSUME ALL THE PLANETS? PLAY VASARI. For example: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=575349424\n\nSeriously though
recommended: get the game on sale. Force your friends to get the game. Practice more than them. Consume their planets."

reviewText: Sins of a Solar Empire has to be one of the most diversified Real Time Strategy Games that I have played within the last Decade of my Life. I have yet to complete very much research into the back story, and lore of each faction, but there is not much of a campaign to speak of either with the Game, so it's up to you to explore which faction you most identify with. There are Three primary Factions which are playable, while each Faction is divided into the primary Faction, and the Extremist Factions each providing their own unique bonuses and strategies. Did I mention there were Pirates in the game, and  they love to collect Bounty. You will have Tons of opportunities to explore the Game during Solo Play with a couple AI Enemies, I would highly encourage this to learn the Ropes of the Game before full immersion into a Multilayer Game. Have you ever felt like creating your own Galaxy, and then try to Conquer it in its entirety? You can do that with a decent Computer and Sins of a Solar Empire. Did I mention how great all the DLC Expansions compliment the Game, and allow for a much more diversified and unique Galaxy each time you begin a new Game? One time I thought it would be Awesome if I could Control an entire Fleet during a space battle after watching Star Wars for the first time in my life, after purchasing Sins of a Solar Empire, my Dreams became a Reality. Would you like your fellow Clan or Guild Members to hail you as the Galactic Emperor? This could be a Reality for you too with this Game, a little practice, and possibly a couple personal pointers from yours truly.. One aspect that I felt was missing from the Game was the ability to Control each Ship yourself, which I think would be fricken Awesome. Ultimately the Game will be as vast as your Imagination, and Free Time will allow; Many games can be finished within Two to Three hours, I also have some on-going Games which might never end. If I were to describe the Game to you from here on through the rest of this Review, I would make sure to include the Fact that you start out with a Home Planet, and through Military Skill, Intelligent Research, swift Expansion to surrounding Planets, dominating your Local Star, Cultural Assimilation, Diplomatic Relations, and Teamwork, you gradually Conquer the Solar System, Planet by Planet. You will eradicate all Competition, punishing Pirates, or placing Bounty on other Players, hiring said Pirates to do your Dirty Work. Did I mention that you can develop each Planet, and harvest the necessary Resources to Build up and Expand your Armada, and Empire? I heard that the Black Market can always provide a quick Economic Stimulus when you're in a Financial Bind, I've never uttered a more true to Life Statement. Don't forget to do your Research, because there are Multiple Tech Trees to Explore and unlock, which provide great Offensive, or Defensive Bonuses, as well as ♥♥♥♥ that helps your Empire expand. Your Fleet may consist of a vast array of unique Ships, each with their own Strengths, depending on your Research Levels, you can quickly Constrict your Opponents to close Proximity Conflicts. One other thing I thought to mention would be the great Modding Community, remember when I was so into Star Wars earlier? There's a Mod for that... Yea when I think of the ultimate Futuristic Space Real Time Strategy Game, Sins of A Solar Empire has become my number One, so go ahead and purchase this game next time you see it on sale, because it is a Great Game, which I feel I have gotten the value of what I had paid for it initially, Ten Fold after my First successful Galactic Conquest. Remember Space is Mankind's final Frontier; Look to the Stars for they are the Future.

reviewText:
For a space RTS game, this is definitely where it's at. Although it doesn't hone the capabilities of taking control of a single ship, it does give a good space fun their fill of fun. Be careful as you can get caught and quickly start pouring hours into single player missions or playing against your friends online! If you are looking for me to expand on the personal story of Sins of a Solar Empire I cannot do it. Why? I don't have enough background information to tell you exactly what the story is but I can tell you how the game holds up! Even if you're not a hardcore space fan, you could most likely easily put 10 hours into the game. This may be in part in how the game develops to play style.

Sins of a Solar Empire is described as an 4X type of game (explore, expand, exploit and exterminate). There is quite a bit to do and manage. To begin, there are three races that the player is able to choose from : the (industrial) TEC, the (psychics) Advent and the (alien zergish looking) Vasari. Each race has it's own unique distinctions and units but all sort of share the same build options regarding ships and buildings alike. The TEC (human race) is not as good technologically as the other races but is good at poking away at opponents slowly (attrition warfare). The Advent race has great energy weapons but lack armor and prefer shields. They also can use their cultural influence on other planets in an attempt to shift opinion. The Vasari beat both the humans and the Advent regarding their technological and ship abilities. However, these high quality ships come at a steep price!

The game play itself is actually pretty good. It's easy to keep track of what's going on from planet to planet and they made it extremely easy to upgrade/build. If you are wanting to upgrade an aspect of a planet (say civilian infrastructure, emergency shelters, exploring more of the planet and (not limited to) industry or social focus), it can be done easily. Managing planets was made with ease while managing fleets takes a bit of work. There are lot of commands in games that the keyboard can take care of. It will take a while to figure out what is what but as long as you know what the icons mean, you're gold. Research and diplomacy can be taken care of by clicking the tabs up top. Research is broken into a few categories in which focuses on either military, defense, diplomatic, civilian infrastructure and fleet upgrades. New units, abilities or even additional damage can added to your arsenal. Be wary though! To create capitol ships or titan units (mega ships), you will need command" staff and will have to upgrade not a unit amount
date: but the command slot amount.\n\nI'm a bit confused regarding single player as there doesn't seem to be a campaign mode. Rather
recommended: it seems they took the approach of single individual missions against the AI. This might irritate a lot of players but may also entice a lot of players into playing single missions. Multiplayer saved games are a bit tricky (see : link discussion). All players must have their own save file but the save file cannot be sent player to player (as one player may be using your race/units). The diplomacy portion of the game is a little weary as well. It's good but nothing too outstanding. Missions can be given to factions and vice versa (as well as trade options and the sort). Completing these missions reflects on your relations with factions. Pirates can also be hired within the game in case you don't want to attack your opponent directly. It can cost you a pretty penny though!\n\nThere are a few things you can tweak in-game considering winning conditions. Default mission settings uses domination
hoursPlayed: which means that you basically have to take over the map. There is a diplomatic victory in which you need to acquire the most diplomatic points to win. Research victory where (obviously) you need to complete the most research or reach a specific tier. There is an occupation victory in which special militia will keep spawning at a certain planet and players must control (occupy) this planet for a certain amount of time. Reaching this time means victory. There are other winning conditions such as capitol planet and capitol ship in which both (or one - your choice) have to stay alive. If your capitol planet becomes occupied
voteText: you lose. If your capitol ship gets destroyed
helpfulPercent: you lose. Within this menu you can also change how many planets are within the map and starting conditions. They give you a decent amount of options to customize your game so you can enjoy how you wish.\n\nThe game's currency system is quite simple and has some nice additions. Coins are your basic income and will need it to buy majority of things. (NOTICE : if you are losing coins and do not know why
votesHelpful: you do not have enough civilian infrastructure on your planets)! Crystals are the next and finally metal. Metal and crystal are harvested from asteroids and can be traded if you build a trade system (increasing your economy). Metal and crystal can be sold or bought. They attempted an interactive market where the prices will drop and rise. The game will give you a small heads-up but it's always a good idea to keep an eye on the prices.\n\nThe visuals themselves are actually decently good. They is a lot of attention to detail and most phaser/ion cannon shots are noticeable. Ships taking damage is also apparent as well as when ships attack planets (you can see mini explosions on the surface)! In addition
votesTotal: you can see traffic moving about the planet and cities. Sounds are pretty good (explosion sounds could vary a bit) and you can hear ships jump from planet to planet. The dialogue in game is good but as most RTS games
votesFunny: you'll start hearing the same voices in your head.\n\nOverall
commentsCount: a pretty good space RTS game. I would recommend it for die-hard space fans and would recommend the casual gamer to buy on sale so there is no love lost. After playing for 10+ hours and playing different game modes (victory conditions)

reviewText: Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is an incredibly in-depth flower shop simulator. I liked how the space theme fits very well in this game - you send flowers to others in space and they send some back to you but I find it hard to believe that you'd need so much resourses to make flowers. However, that must have been a design choice that I just don't understand yet.\n\nI give this game 2 fertilizers out of 1 sprout.

The gameplay mechanics do take experience to master, but that's all part of what makes the game so wonderful; there are so many aspects of gameplay to take into consideration when you are in a match, such as culture, research topics, and etcetera. If you think that all you have to do to prevail in a match of Sins is to build a thousand ships and spam orbital cannons, you are sorely mistaken.

One thing that appeals to me personally about Sins is the fact that, right from the beginning, you have to meticulously plan out each detail of your empire's expansion, taking into consideration events that could potentially happen hours later.

That planet with only one phase lane leading into enemy territory? Chances are your enemy will eventually try to punch through. You'll need to plan for that.

The world on the other side of the map that's just starting to produce culture? It will spread to your planets quickly. You'll need to plan for that.

That TEC Loyalist player on the other side of the map whose planet pings up for a second with a superweapon alert? You'll especially need to plan for that.

The one and only downside for me about Sins is, and I'm sure this is a common one, there's no campaign! The franchise has gone into a good deal of detail creating a backstory, seriously, there's a whole bunch of story content out there. What I would really like to see is an actual in-game campaign in which you can follow one of the three main empires on their quests within this storyline. Another little want of mine is to have a campaign constructor. That would be amazing. If these things were there, a 10/10 game.

It's pretty much impossible to get bored of Sins, each game turns out differently from the last. But if, however, you somehow manage to get bored, there's but one thing for that: mods. This game has a Star Trek mod, and subsequently has my seal of approval.

This game is amazing. I myself have had endless hours of fun with Sins, and reccommend this entirely to everybody. Get this game right now.

reviewText:
Alrighty, as a hardcore enthusiast of RTS and similar strategy games, this worked it's way into my top 3. The online scene is a little dead, but that doesnt take away from the fact that this is a fantastic game.

There are 3 things that set this apart from most other RTS's I have played:
1) The diplomacy is challenging as you have to build a relationship with a faction. Unlike other games with diplomacy mechanics, you really have to work at it.
2) The resources are scarce. It's not like Starcraft where you can just start mass-producing probes/drones/scvs to boost your economy intake. You need to manage resources and take advantage of the refining boosts you get through research.
3) The research tree. This is probably one of the most standard mechanic of any good RTS, and because of that I have seen some terrible tech trees. This game however has a balanced tech tree that allows for a little variability in expanding and is grouped into nice little sections for easier maintenance. I like this a LOT.

Aside from these three things, the game is also visually appealing, with an interesting (if a bit cliche) backstory and lots of available strategies for play. The only true downsides are the somewhat annoying and repetitive unit voices, the rather repetitive soundtrack, and the steep, steep learning curve.

In any case, I give this a 9/10. Excellent game to pick up if you dont mind spending an hour or 2 per match.

reviewText:
This is a 4x game. There are 3 races and with the DLC 1 new faction for each race is added, bringing the total 'races' you can play up to 6. For a single player game it takes me around 3.5 hours, and thats with 2 hard bots one easy bot and me. Multiplayer is even more fun, since u can colab and even help move each other around (the vasari rebels share their phase tech).

I dont think ive ever uninstalled this game. This is my default time sink game, and its fun every time. If you like Sword of the Stars, you will like this, only difference is the smaller tech pool and you cant modify your ships hardpoints. I just wish that the publisher would release more dlc (like this is a really bad complaint). If you like 4x, the idea of having ships so big that they are the size of planets, and commanding multiple fleets in realtime to own the galaxy, then this is a game for YOU! ^_^

eXplore: planets for artifacts, the galaxy for planets and your enemy
eXperiment: research your titan your factions ultra-flagship, can macross missles with lasers!
eXpand: that oceanic world would be perfect to house the seat of your propganda machine!
eXtermanate: TITANS dont change the flow of the battle, titans are a wave that assure victory.

tl;dr compare other 4X to this.

reviewText:
If you love strategy, compiling of unique races and factions, and wide variety of territory to conquer, this is the Game for you. You even control the rate at which things get built, resources earned, how fast ships travel, and speed of many other attributes to the game, using settings, if you choose. If you love random replayability where one game you can win, but the next with all the same settings, but game developed differently from beginning, becomes a little more difficult and you lose; this game is for you!

If you enjoy production genre of space shows, like; Star Trek, Star Wars, Battlestar Gallactica, and other scifi shows/movies about Galactic control, this game is for you. Everything I mentioned, I enjoy! I also enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization Series, Empire Earth, Command and Conquer, Galactic Civilization II, Age of Empires series, Master of Orion series, Star Craft the original, and many more. To give you an idea of this game compared to some of my favorites I listed... SoaSE:R (or SINS for short), has kind of a Star Craft three different races feel, mixed with the massive galactic control and Diplomacy of Master of Orion, and a fast pace strategy set of Empire Earth and Age of Empires, however to experience the unique faction diversity set between each of the three main Races, their is no real comparison... you just have to Experience Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion for your self.

I personally love the Vasari Loyalist; Their unique ability to create their own phase lanes and travel between stars as they see fit, with their Kostura Cannon attack of defenses on a target leaving its own Phase Node behind, matched with the Titan's powerful warship and ability to terrorize enemy forces jumping around inside planet's Gravity Wells, as well as around the different planets, are some reasons why I enjoy the Vasari Loyalist!

However, nothing can match the Cultural power of the Advent, and their ability to manipulate the culture across the Galaxy with their super weapon Deliverance engine casting a massive culture bomb behind enemy lines. If timed right, having a powerful armada close to a target for culture bomb, and the right research, Advent forces can get a huge combat bonus within your own culture, in side the enemy bases if fighting within the culture bomb influence. They also have many power mind control abilities to take away many ships!

Nothing compares to the Massive economic power of the TEC (Trader Emergency Coalition), and their ability to expand fast and cover the cost, and earn much more power through commerce compared to the other two. TEC also can coerce the Pirates factions, and all natives across the Galaxy to side with them, creating an unwavering force of friendly support  across the map, and cause relentless waves of mild assaults by unforeseen pirate raids among different Enemy bases!

If played right, any of the three races, and the split factions within, can become a powerful force to be reconned with! Can YOU build an Empire, to Stand the Test of SPACE and TIME?

If still interested, feel free to check my steam profile... I have many screenshots, already posted... and more going up all the time!

reviewText:
So the game was on sale, it was set in space, and was listed as a Multiplayer, stratagy game..

'Worth a look' I thought. I watched the trailer, and was bored half way through.. But, it does boast some impressive stuff sooo 'Lets watch some in-game vids on youtube' I thought to myself.

2 mins in, I had purchased a 4 pack for me and some buddies. I was actually sat on the edge of my sofa waiting for the game to install.. It looked complex from what I could see.. but hey, that makes the game better!

Now as much as I want to recommend the tutorials..  it did take me 3 hours to run through all the tutorials, just because they're are as boring as hell to do. They did however prepare me for some basic gameplay so in I jumped ready for some action!

Now skipping past my first few games, or the learning phase, as I call it. I put myself against 3 Ai and no word of a lie, it lasted over 9 hours. The game took so many turns it was untrue.. one moment I was winning hands down, then it all collapsed around me as my culture was taken over! I then brought it back again only to have the Ai turn things around again.. It all sounds horrible but infact it was incredible fun! For a game to be so well built that you can turn your hand to something different to bring it all back again is great.

Multiplayer is also great fun.. you can team up or go FFA.. Even during FFA you can raise your diplomacy with your friends, and/or your enemies. While your friend and you are teaming together to bring an enemy faction down, you can be employing other races to form against your friend, leaving them defenceless for when you decide to declare war again ;)

For fans of older games like 'Birth of the Federation' 'Star wars Supremacy' 'Homeworld' or Civilisation, then be prepared to lose yourself inan absolutely incredible stratagy game!

I was only made aware of this game due to a steam sale, but it is well worth the £29.99 price tag.

reviewText:
I had prepped the largest fleet in the system for an invasion of the final enemy's homeworld. Including ships that could take on full fleets by themselves. And sent them to the planet. When they arrived, a giant ♥♥♥♥off space station, armed to the bloody teeth, began slaughtering my fleet from the bottom up, first the corvettes, then the frigates, then the cruisers, etc. Then their titan warped in to engage my own, and with that, I had to order my last few ships into retreat. Only my titan managed to, on about 1% hp, limp back to my forward base, the enemy fleet right behind it.

Then I got mad and fired my two planet-destroyer nuclear cannons hidden on the other side of the star system as a backup plan, in case the glorious frontal assault didn't work, and genocided the ♥♥♥♥ out of them, destroying an entire culture in just 2 shots.

8/10 would space again

Actual review: Large scale, slooooow paced RTS with some nice space battles, easy to use interface (one you learn where everything is), some nice variety in the factions, and an interesting dynamic with the neutral fleets of militia and pirates that will launch their own periodic assaults on your worlds and trade routes. Graphics understandably look a little rough up close, and it requires a significant time investment per game, and the ability to form fleet formations would be nice, but overall, a damn solid space RTS.

Think of a mix between Civ/similar and Supreme Commander/similar. That's about what you get here. Well worth picking up the next time you see it on sale.

reviewText:
Pros:
- The factions are unique and immersive. Everything from the voice acting to the UI changes with each faction and the special abilities of each really gives a flavor to playing each faction.
- Truly customizable fleets. Every ship/cruiser has a special ability that is further customized to the faction you are playing. Ever wanted a fleet that could push enemy ships away? A ship that can draw aggro? A ship that takes control of other units? It's a lot of fun.
- Extremely good pacing. I felt like I could actually finish a game with my friends but it isn't so fast that you feel rushed or overwhelmed.
- If you play through the tutorials, you have a good enough grasp of the game to enjoy the game, but the game actually has a lot of depth to explore to make more intricate strategies
- Beautiful graphics for the ships and planets. I wish it was easier to play with your ships actually visible and not icons, but I love the amount of detail when you have time to zoom in and watch a battle up close.
- Pirates are bad ♥♥♥. Whether you are fighting them or using them against people. I love that you can physically hunt down the pirate bases and get some well earned payback.

Cons
- Diplomacy still seems somewhat clunky to me. Instead of starting in a cease fire with everyone, everyone pretty much starts in a cold war. Trying to contact someone means dodging their ships as they try to destroy you and hoping your envoys can survive long enough to make it to a cease fire. The missions are a great idea but are hard to utilize since they usually are attack this person we don't like" with no consideration of your relationship with them or even if you know where they are!

reviewText:
Ok so lets start.  First off, the time listed played, is one match + the tutorial.  I played only one single player map.  The smallest one.  The time it took me to finish it was over 8 hours.  Again this was the first single player map and listed as tiny.

Now I will admit.  Part of that was cause I was still getting use to the game.  I also kinda limited my self to only upgrading war and defensive upgrades.  Leaving out anything that was trade or peace related.  This makes it hard cause those upgrades I did not use would help capture some planet types, give better material gathering, give more money, and allow peaceful relations with others in the system so that they did not attack you or even might help ya.

So ya, 8 hours for one tiny map.

This game is fun for anyone who like strategy and long game play.  Do not get this game thinking it will be a quick run.  There are ways to change the victory setting and not sure how the competitive play fairs.  I would imagine there might be some ways to make it go faster.

Also, as far as I can see.  There is no storyline or quest line.  This is not like Starcraft.  You are not doing RTS with a rich story about 3 different races.  Your basically playing a glorified chess game.  A MASSIVE, BEAUTIFUL, not really that close to chess, chess game.

I was listening to a coworker talk about it and the vids I saw made it look good enough to try.  It is, but it is really only good for eating up your time.  Need something to just throw countless hours at were there is no story and just plotting and building your forces in hopes you can take out your enemies.  Then go for it.

Though if you are not absolutely sure then do what I did and get it at 75% or more off.

reviewText:
A good grand RTS game of scale comparable to Supreme Commander but in space.

You can fight on 'maps' that are anywhere from a single star surrounded by only a few planets to a few stars with upwards of a hundred varied planets, from dwarf planets and giant asteroids to molten and ice covered planets.

There are three factions, both with a loyalist and a rebel side to choose from that mostly comes to a choice of offense vs. defense. And it even has mod support with no shortage of mods to choose from be it Star Trek, Star Wars, or even the Stargate SG1 series among other mods that add whole new factions not pulled from other scifi.

Taking planets could be more interesting, given that you can only bombard them into oblivion or overwhelm a planet with your culture to break it's loyalty down. Combat itself isn't too involved either, most any abilities are auto-cast and there's nothing dynamic about the damage system. It can become a bit boring after a while because of that but this is a grand strategy so what's to expect.

There is zero reason to pick up the previous games because every single release, including this game, since the original's release has been a DLC pack.

reviewText:
Before I say anything, I want you people to know that the supposed 2 hours I have in this game are on ONLINE mode. I use mods and play offline a lot, so there should be like 324 hours logged up, but steam doesn't log offline gameplay. Anyway, let me get on with it.

This game is absolutely stunning. The graphics are amazing, the AI is very well balanced and smart, and the overall gameplay is absolutely mindblowing. There are hundreds and hundreds of hours worth of gameplay sitting right there waiting for you to buy it. At first, you start off at one planet, your capital planet, and you working on your economy and researching as much as you can. You send off small fleets to neighboring planets to gain control of them and wipe out the garrisons. This cycle continues for around 20 minutes, where you slowly expand your control and research tons of new ships and technology. Eventually, you are able to amass HUGE fleets and hunt down the hostile faction. This is just a small example of how incredibly fun the gameplay is. I have NEVER gotten bored.

So what're you waiting for? Buy it.
20/10

reviewText:
Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a fantastic example of what can be done with a 4X RTS. It excels in so many ways it’s difficult to narrow them all down, but in short, its main pull is that it provides the depth and time not seen in many of the other RTS games out there. That being said, the games in Sins tend to take anywhere from 40 minutes, to 4 hours, so anyone who wants a shorter, more fast paced experience should look elsewhere.

On a very important side note, the multitude of mods out there can REALLY improve the experience. Three I'd personally recommend are: Sins of a Galactic Empire (A Star Wars based mod), Enhanced 4X, and Sins of the Prophets (Halo based).

reviewText:
:THIS REVIEW IS SOMEWHAT BIAS:

This game provides you the thrill of controlling an empire that listens to every command you make. Whether it is wiping an entire race from it's existence, or building a giant cannon that shoots the image of god to an enemy home world, either way it's really fun.  You get to choose between three factions, each containing the Loyalists(True Empire) or the Rebels, with various ways of winning the game.

The factions are and contain the following empires:
T.E.C. : Loyalists and Rebels
Vasari: Loyalists and Rebels
Advent:Loyalists and Rebels

Each faction has their own personal upgrades that shared between the the two empires in that faction, along  with their own personal ships, star bases, culture, and more. And depending the empire you choose you have to use different victory options and strategies. And one common thing that all players have to deal with are space pirates. Although they are annoying, they can be dealt with pretty easily especially late game. Your currency for all empires are called credits, along with metal and crystals. In order to have a good functioning empire you need all the three in order to purchase ships, research new technologies, and to grow.

Positives:
Intelligent A.I. (especially in combat)
Detailed ships,planets, and structures
Allows mods (Star Trek, Star Wars, Battle Star Galactica,etc)
High replayability
Easy to learn with helpful tutorial


Negatives:
Ships and structures can sometimes use auto use (Which makes them use a special ability) even after disabled
Pirates generally attack only one empire the whole game, very hard to pay off
Constant connection and save problems when playing online
Constant supervision of planets, ships,etc

That is all I can really remember at this time, note that this review is somewhat incomplete due to my bias opinion and my inexperience in the game. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys awesome space battles, hardcore strategy, and management.

reviewText:
An unprecedentedly complex strategy game that has sucked an impressive amount of my time into its machinations.

As a fervent player of strategy games, I know more than most about the quality and standard of modern strategy games. Thus, it was to my pleasure to find that the gameplay of this game took me completely by surprise. When I purchased this game (due to a passing recommendation by a friend) I was expecting a mediocre 'annihilate-and-win' type of strategy game. What I found instead was a game that truly catered for just about any type of strategy player. One can win via a multiple of ways spanning from cultural domination to research to the common exterminate victory to name just a few. The cultural element of the game was a particularly impressive feature. As a strategist who prefers to punch my enemies into submission, I realized that the threat posed by a culturally superior race only too late in my first few games, where I believed I was winning the game through annihilation. Hence, unlike most strategy games, those who prefer to fortify and dig into their defences can technically still win the game without firing a single shot into the enemy ranks.

The resource accumilation and the ship upkeep features tends to keep most players in check, ensuring that no particular player can expand so quickly that he should overwhelm a coalition of players teaming up against him. This is a neat feature, as it forces players to think cunningly, lest too many of his enemies turn against him united in hate or paranoia.

Amongst other notable features, I also found the time taken to travel between planets to be a key feature of this game. I had not originally known that travelling between say... 4 planets would take a decent amount of time. This means by the time my main fleet arrives to defend a planet under siege, it has probably already been raised to the ground. Hence, players are forced to pre-empt incoming attacks or opt to divide and conquer.

The multiplayer experience is quite enjoyable as this game seems to have a relatively small but extremely friendly following. I was pleasantly surprised to find there are plenty of new players to the multiplayer experience as well as veterans who can teach a newcomer a thing or two.

Overall, Sins of a Solar Empire ranks very, very highly amongst my favourite strategy games. While the visuals of the game is not entirely awe-inspiring, it is very obvious the developers paid a significant portion of their time working on the mechanics of the game. I am happy to say that personally for me, their hard work has paid off and left a very satisfied player in their wake.

Overall Score: 9/10 - Extremely satisfying to play, would highly recommend.

reviewText:
GREAT GAME. Extremely high replay value.

Back in the day, I played a game called Pax Imperia and its sequel Eminent Domain. In many ways, Sins of a Solar Empire looks, feels, and plays like the successor to these games.
______________________________________

Pros:
• Tutorials are fairly short and adequately teach gameplay.
• Many AI difficulty settings means the game will continue to be challenging for experienced players.
• Autosave feature is unobtrusive. Autosave feature keeps a full-game history, allowing you to go back to any point.
• 6 different victory types which can selectively be turned off/on.
• Good soundtrack. Almost all voiceovers are well done.
• Very large selection of pre-made maps, can randomly generate maps of any size, and comes with a map designer.
• Each race features a completely unique tech tree and set of units. Large selection of unit types each with their own skills.
• Diplomacy system is understandable and works well.
• With the amount of customization present, it's likely the next release in this series will be out long before you are bored with this game.
• Map navigation is easy and intuitive.
______________________________________

Cons:
• While the background universe Ironclad Games has developed is cool, there is no story mode."
• No customization of races or factions (one of my favorite features from Eminent Domain).
• One voiceover is not very good and it annoys me every time I hear it.
• Tech trees can be slightly overwhelming on the first couple games.
• I wish it had more cosmetic options (such as changable ship skins
recommended:
etc).
• Hotkeys are difficult to learn.
______________________________________

Other Comments:
• DRM is nothing to worry about

reviewText: I'll admit, I was one of those people who played the original for about 30 minutes and became confused at how technical and fiddly it all seemed, so gave up. However when SoaSE : R was put on a hefty sale, I decided to do some research and after watching some YT videos of mods and other awesome moments, and with copious positive reviews both on and offline, I decided to pick it up. I'll say right now, that it's still a very fiddly game, but I've sunk about 2 evenings worth of time playing it and even more time thinking about it. It's easily one of the most proficient games when it comes to Fleet management and empire building in a Sci-Fi genre. Solid mechanics, excellent economy system and fantastic battle simulations (could still be better with more animated battles, but the particle effects and light shows are still great to watch). If you need a good comparison of a game, think Supreme Commander fused with Civilization.\n\nDefinitely worth a buy. =D

reviewText:
This game is a hostile space colony management simulation. Wonderful graphics and charm, intense battles, sketchy relations, and all around stressful empire building will await you. This game is not a walk in the park, it's more of a 12 mile race to the finish. Except throw in brutal fighting.

Fleet makeup and upkeep can make or break you when it comes to defending and expanding your empire. There are many ship types, and a general understanding of each will certainly help.

Creating and maintaning relations is nessecary for anything close to survival, and failing to do some can result in horrible repricutions ranging from pirate raids to general raiding from other players or AI.

Managing your economy, as in any rts, is something that should be learned and practiced from start if you plan to do well. Managing your planets and fleets, and upgrading your tech to assist in that should be seconded only to combating other factions.

SoaSER is a great, if slow, game. I give it a 8/10

reviewText:
Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is perhaps my favourite game out of those that I currently own, there are just so many features  and games will last you several hours. Few games have such a high level of replayability and sheer fun factor but Sins manages it with ease. Each faction is well balanced and unique, the split between Loyalists and Rebels is a nice touch, perhaps there could have been slightly more to seperate the two but it's not a pressing issue and they are unique enough.

graphically the game looks impressive, models and textures are of high quality so people who enjoy their shiny games won't be dissapointed. The only particular issue with the game is the engine Ironclad used, it's very old and only uses a single core. Sadly this means no matter how beastly your rig is, during large battles with big fleets the game WILL stutter.

If that doesn't put you off then Sins is well worth a buy, plus the game has modding support with a very active modding community that have made some fantastic mods. While you may not personally wants Sins itself (but it is good so do try it out) there are well developed mods including Halo, Mass Effect and Stargate and a Homeworld mod.

Just for refference I have an i7-3930k clocked at 3.8ghz and the game still loses massive frames and stutters duing big battles. So do keep in mind the engine limitations...I wouldn't mind a Rebellion Remastered on a better engine Ironclad. Wink, wink, nudge, nudge.

reviewText: This is a real gem, a very thoughtfully crafted game. Even as late as 2014, I might call it the best game since Civ4 came out in 2005. The basic setup is almost cliche: three factions, three types of resources, spend those resources on tech/buildings/units, kill enemy. However, it distinguishes itself in several ways to become a truly great game. First, you play at both a macro and micro level and everything between, and the game somehow makes this seemingly incompatible mix of scales work unbelievably well. Second, unlike many RTS it is not all about APM, as it proceeds at a pace where deliberative thought is possible. It is an RTS that might appeal to TBS players. Third, despite the slower pace there's still plenty to do, because it does a great job in presenting the user with interesting meaningful and situationally appropriate choices, from where and how to spend resources, how aggressively to push, and with what ships. You're constantly making choices, and the game somehow manages that precise balance only the greatest games do of making you never quite comfortable with that choice.\n\nOne flaw: The learning curve is steep without a campaign. It's not a complex game, really. It's easily playable with nothing more than a mouse, after all. However, it takes a while to appreciate that and let the true depth of the game shine through. I understand things more or less well now, but it was a hard slog. (To save time: Read GoaFan77's guide, every last word of it. I didn't have that advantage when I started.)
