reviewText:
I would strongly recommend this game to any fan of real time strategy that really loves space based games. Although initially the game might have a steep learning curve once learned it gives great pleasure and infinite hours of fun.

Pros
+ Impressive graphics for a real time strategy game
+ Three different races with different playstyles
+ Hours of sandbox campaign fun (against AI or other players online)
+ Tech research tree different for each faction
+ Spectacular space battles
+ Great music

Cons
- Lack of campaign mode (your campaign is what you do in sandbox mode so you need some immagination)
- More in depth planetary administration would be nice
- Lack of an in depth lore for the game

Overall for me is a solid 8/10. This game really need just more features and variety to shine. DLCs help in this regard however more are needed. A campaign is a must here.
In conclusion should you buy this game? Yes if you like real time strategy set in space and have one or two good friends to play the game with. You won't be disappointed. Buy it with all the DLCs though to have a complete experience.

reviewText:
This game is a hostile space colony management simulation. Wonderful graphics and charm, intense battles, sketchy relations, and all around stressful empire building will await you. This game is not a walk in the park, it's more of a 12 mile race to the finish. Except throw in brutal fighting.

Fleet makeup and upkeep can make or break you when it comes to defending and expanding your empire. There are many ship types, and a general understanding of each will certainly help.

Creating and maintaning relations is nessecary for anything close to survival, and failing to do some can result in horrible repricutions ranging from pirate raids to general raiding from other players or AI.

Managing your economy, as in any rts, is something that should be learned and practiced from start if you plan to do well. Managing your planets and fleets, and upgrading your tech to assist in that should be seconded only to combating other factions.

SoaSER is a great, if slow, game. I give it a 8/10

reviewText:
One of the best RTS 4X strategy games out there.

This game is about pure survival, you will try to use whatever tool necessary to make sure your empire sees another day.
It offers the four mighty Xs, Exploring the darkest corners of the solar systems or entire sectors. Expanding your empire by colonizing all kinds of different planets, asteroids and stations. Gathering basic resources which you need for your empire's growth and most importantly eliminating rival opponents in both single or multiplayer matches.

One of the greatest features of this game is actually the option to zoom in onto even the smallest objects in the space. Therefore you can enjoy some really beautiful sights of awesome ship and building models and space battles.
You can take control over large amount of ships which you can even asign into custom fleets to ease issuing commands.
The game's soundtracks are one of the best I've listened to while playing any kind of strategy games, simply marvelous.

Both single player and multiplayer gameplay is really smooth and solid. All the base game races are surprisingly well balanced. Every race has its pros and cons, but they share a kind of a basic setup from where the different specializations start off. What really surprised me about this game is that you can actually host a multiplayer match on a public IP with an access to your router's port-forwarding rather than crating LAN or Official lobbies.

There are few things that actually dissapoint me about this game.
One of them is the lack of any sort of story based missions or a campaign, which is really a shame, because the littly backstory of this game is really interesting and is surely worth pointing out.
The other, but not the last thing is about the not very efficient AI difficulty levels.
Using increased income bonuses and faster research as a buff for higher difficulty AI is in my opinion wrong move and it is nearly impossible to defeat highest difficulty AI in a regular match just on your own, without anyone else to balance the enormous pressure on, because the enemy's economy overcomes you in just few minutes into the game.

Other great thing worth pointing out is the support for mods. There are plenty of awesome mods out there, which can really spice up the gameplay of the base game or add an entire new experience with something new, using conversions.

As of the DLCs, If you find yourself enjoying this game at first, and you kinda get into it I certainly recommend adding both of them into your game as each of them adds some minor things and tweaks that can really improve the overall gameplay experience of every match you play.

I've played this game for more than a thousand hours in total off-steam and I enjoy every battle I manage to win or lose decisively or just by a pure luck. SoaSER is love, SoaSER is life.

Without anything more to say, I would rate this game by 9/10 for how awesome it is.

reviewText:
This is a game of patience, but oh man, will your patience be rewarded. Matches can concievably be played over the course of a few days, with fleets of apocalyptic proportions being the end result, blasting eachother into oblivion. Battles start small and get very, very big in scale as they go on, and the game even has a sweet cinemetic option that makes it easier to watch the space combat. Just don't do that in a serious fight or you'll find your ships exploding without you around to control them.

The factions are slightly reminiscant of Starcraft's, with the defensive humans, offensive genetics-minded evil aliens and fanatical religious psychics. Space battles are fun but the game truly becomes great when you get diplomacy involved and start paying serious attention to economics, the game gives you alot of time to think and it's at it's most fun when that time is spent controlling as many of the intricate pieces in the game as possible.

Definitely worth everything, highly reccomended to anyone who likes to take things slow and play mastermind.

reviewText:
This game is an RTS - 4X hybrid (which focuses a lot more onthe RTS aspect), featuring three different races with two factions each (Rebels and Loyalists). Each faction is a bit different from the other, while they share base similarities.
This last expansion, which is now also standalone, has all the features (and more) than the previous ones had: Diplomacy and Entrenchment.
I do quite like it, I've spent many hours on it and I do suggest you buy it if you like RTS games that are set in space. It's pretty unique on itself because of the rather uncommon lore the game has; there's no story nor any form of campaign, you are given the races and a bunch of maps (quite big bunch in fact) and you just play. I hope that the backstories of each race are expanded upon with any further release/DLC and I hope that some day we see official campaigns, meanwhile we still have the map creator tools.

It also is mod compatible, even online.
Has pretty grafix and doesn't play too bad, although the framerate will progressively decrease on big maps with lots of AI players and units (sometimes to the point of having a 20fps slideshow, but the slideshow is still pretty!)
New units and all that yadda.

Overall 8.7/10 Would recommend again.

reviewText:
An unprecedentedly complex strategy game that has sucked an impressive amount of my time into its machinations.

As a fervent player of strategy games, I know more than most about the quality and standard of modern strategy games. Thus, it was to my pleasure to find that the gameplay of this game took me completely by surprise. When I purchased this game (due to a passing recommendation by a friend) I was expecting a mediocre 'annihilate-and-win' type of strategy game. What I found instead was a game that truly catered for just about any type of strategy player. One can win via a multiple of ways spanning from cultural domination to research to the common exterminate victory to name just a few. The cultural element of the game was a particularly impressive feature. As a strategist who prefers to punch my enemies into submission, I realized that the threat posed by a culturally superior race only too late in my first few games, where I believed I was winning the game through annihilation. Hence, unlike most strategy games, those who prefer to fortify and dig into their defences can technically still win the game without firing a single shot into the enemy ranks.

The resource accumilation and the ship upkeep features tends to keep most players in check, ensuring that no particular player can expand so quickly that he should overwhelm a coalition of players teaming up against him. This is a neat feature, as it forces players to think cunningly, lest too many of his enemies turn against him united in hate or paranoia.

Amongst other notable features, I also found the time taken to travel between planets to be a key feature of this game. I had not originally known that travelling between say... 4 planets would take a decent amount of time. This means by the time my main fleet arrives to defend a planet under siege, it has probably already been raised to the ground. Hence, players are forced to pre-empt incoming attacks or opt to divide and conquer.

The multiplayer experience is quite enjoyable as this game seems to have a relatively small but extremely friendly following. I was pleasantly surprised to find there are plenty of new players to the multiplayer experience as well as veterans who can teach a newcomer a thing or two.

Overall, Sins of a Solar Empire ranks very, very highly amongst my favourite strategy games. While the visuals of the game is not entirely awe-inspiring, it is very obvious the developers paid a significant portion of their time working on the mechanics of the game. I am happy to say that personally for me, their hard work has paid off and left a very satisfied player in their wake.

Overall Score: 9/10 - Extremely satisfying to play, would highly recommend.

reviewText:
I like the gameplay of Sins of a Solar Empire (SSE), but I hated the fact that there was no single-player campaign to tie it all together. It looked like the game had a story to tell, but it never tells it. So you're stuck playing skirmishes against the AI or playing skirmishes against real people. So it gets repetitive after a while, but the idea of getting out there and exploring a new galaxy brings you back after a break. I really wish Stardock had taken the time to make a single-player campaign. They did it for GalCiv, why not for this?

Pros:
- The creation of the Mega Cruisers is nice
- The factions create more Mega Cruisers

Cons:
- Still no campaign
- The factions really do nothing besides create more Mega Cruisers

reviewText:
Great RTS space game!

Variety is better than I expected as each race plays very differently from the others.

My favorite thing about this game is the fact that it takes longer than other RTS's to win. Games can take 2-8 hours depending on settings. If you are on a very big map with multiple players or AI then games can even take 20+ hours to finish. PvP multiplayer games however can be as short as 20 minutes or as long as 6 hours. The AI comes in several difficulties. The higher difficulties give a great challenge that no other RTS AI I have played can match.

The game comes with a map builder so you can make any type and size map that you want to suit your needs

8/10 Highly recommend! Great AI, great gameplay, great balance, amazing graphics, and challenging multiplayer. For new players It may take a while to learn the controls and what everything does; the tutorials aren't as detailed as they could be so this knocks my score down a notch

reviewText:
GREAT GAME. Extremely high replay value.

Back in the day, I played a game called Pax Imperia and its sequel Eminent Domain. In many ways, Sins of a Solar Empire looks, feels, and plays like the successor to these games.
______________________________________

Pros:
• Tutorials are fairly short and adequately teach gameplay.
• Many AI difficulty settings means the game will continue to be challenging for experienced players.
• Autosave feature is unobtrusive. Autosave feature keeps a full-game history, allowing you to go back to any point.
• 6 different victory types which can selectively be turned off/on.
• Good soundtrack. Almost all voiceovers are well done.
• Very large selection of pre-made maps, can randomly generate maps of any size, and comes with a map designer.
• Each race features a completely unique tech tree and set of units. Large selection of unit types each with their own skills.
• Diplomacy system is understandable and works well.
• With the amount of customization present, it's likely the next release in this series will be out long before you are bored with this game.
• Map navigation is easy and intuitive.
______________________________________

Cons:
• While the background universe Ironclad Games has developed is cool, there is no story mode."
• No customization of races or factions (one of my favorite features from Eminent Domain).
• One voiceover is not very good and it annoys me every time I hear it.
• Tech trees can be slightly overwhelming on the first couple games.
• I wish it had more cosmetic options (such as changable ship skins
recommended:
etc).
• Hotkeys are difficult to learn.
______________________________________

Other Comments:
• DRM is nothing to worry about

reviewText:
I would strongly recommend this game to any fan of real time strategy that really loves space based games. Although initially the game might have a steep learning curve once learned it gives great pleasure and infinite hours of fun.

Pros
+ Impressive graphics for a real time strategy game
+ Three different races with different playstyles
+ Hours of sandbox campaign fun (against AI or other players online)
+ Tech research tree different for each faction
+ Spectacular space battles
+ Great music

Cons
- Lack of campaign mode (your campaign is what you do in sandbox mode so you need some immagination)
- More in depth planetary administration would be nice
- Lack of an in depth lore for the game

Overall for me is a solid 8/10. This game really need just more features and variety to shine. DLCs help in this regard however more are needed. A campaign is a must here.
In conclusion should you buy this game? Yes if you like real time strategy set in space and have one or two good friends to play the game with. You won't be disappointed. Buy it with all the DLCs though to have a complete experience.

reviewText:
This game is an RTS - 4X hybrid (which focuses a lot more onthe RTS aspect), featuring three different races with two factions each (Rebels and Loyalists). Each faction is a bit different from the other, while they share base similarities.
This last expansion, which is now also standalone, has all the features (and more) than the previous ones had: Diplomacy and Entrenchment.
I do quite like it, I've spent many hours on it and I do suggest you buy it if you like RTS games that are set in space. It's pretty unique on itself because of the rather uncommon lore the game has; there's no story nor any form of campaign, you are given the races and a bunch of maps (quite big bunch in fact) and you just play. I hope that the backstories of each race are expanded upon with any further release/DLC and I hope that some day we see official campaigns, meanwhile we still have the map creator tools.

It also is mod compatible, even online.
Has pretty grafix and doesn't play too bad, although the framerate will progressively decrease on big maps with lots of AI players and units (sometimes to the point of having a 20fps slideshow, but the slideshow is still pretty!)
New units and all that yadda.

Overall 8.7/10 Would recommend again.

reviewText:
Serious Review time? Ok Fine

Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is a unique space RTS games that centers around moving from planet to planet conquering and establishing your empire. The closest thing you can compare this game to is like playing CiV 5 in space, but its in real time.

Other than the homeworld franchise and a little nastalgic empire at war, this is one of the only space RTS games in existence that not only does not suck more than a tai hooker, but it actually pretty well done. Featuring massive and i mean massive battles between fleets of ships by the end game your ships will probably ram into eachother from a siezure because of all the laser beams flying everywhere.

As previously stated you start on 1 planet that revolves around 1 star, you then migrate to neighboring planets exterminating anything you come across around the planet, then you invade and conquer the ♥♥♥♥ out of it like a space age christopher columbus. Maps however can be extremely large, featuring multiple stars, each with their own set of planets revolving around them to conquer and add to the might of your empire.

Oh did i mention when you attack a planet already controlled by another main faction of the game you literally nuke it from orbit (because its the only way to be sure) until everyone dies and you can recolonize it, if that isnt enough for you then i dont know what is.

The reason i also say this game is a real time space version of civ 5 is because the game moves at a slow enough pace that you are playing an RTS, but at the same time you can manage your empire and economy etc with ease. The game also has one of the most well done camera systems ive seen in an RTS game, allowing you can look and go anywhere despite the map being gigantic, all with the simplicity of a scroll wheel.

But seriously, one of the best space rts games in existence, So if you are into either i would absolutely recommend buying it. Ever since i bought the original game its given me YEARS of entertainment.

reviewText:
Great RTS space game!

Variety is better than I expected as each race plays very differently from the others.

My favorite thing about this game is the fact that it takes longer than other RTS's to win. Games can take 2-8 hours depending on settings. If you are on a very big map with multiple players or AI then games can even take 20+ hours to finish. PvP multiplayer games however can be as short as 20 minutes or as long as 6 hours. AI games typically take longer to complete depending on your play style

The AI comes in several difficulties. The higher difficulties give a great challenge that no other RTS AI I have played can match.

The game comes with a map builder so you can make any type and size map that you want to suit your needs

8/10 Highly recommend! Great AI, great gameplay, great balance, amazing graphics, and challenging multiplayer. For new players It may take a while to learn the controls and what everything does; the tutorials aren't as detailed as they could be so this knocks my score down a notch

reviewText:
Probably one of the best Space RTS' available besides Homeworld RM. Basically Risk in real time. Build your fleets, conquer planets and build your empire using varrious ships from light frigates, support cruisers, capitalships and giant titans. Definetly worth your time if your a RTS Fan.

Pros:
-Build massive fleets and control empires that span whole galaxines in real time.
-3 races with 2 sub factions each which diffrent buffs and special ships.
-Varrious game modes which give many routes to victory or defeat.

Cons:
-Not optimised for modern systems, requires Large Adress Aware program to utilize systems with more RAM.
-More Macro then Micro, though Micro does come in to play some times.
-Large massive maps with maxed fleets can cause heavy sutter/lag.

reviewText:
Although Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion lacks a campaign that so many gamers love and look for, it more than makes up for this by atmosphere, scale, and depth. Sins of a Solar Empire is one of those games balanced in such a way that there's no clear balance. That doesn't mean it's bad, it just means that each race (the Vasari, the TEC, and the Advent) have different playing styles.

In contrast to games such as StarCraft, where everone knows the three races have their own triangle of defeat (Zerg beats Protoss, Protoss beats Terran, and Terran beats Zerg), Sins of a Solar Empire is all about your strategy. Will you expand your space outwards, take planets and conquer the enemy, or will you lie in wait until the time is right?

The scale of the game is truely marvelous, but often goes overlooked. The zoom function is really helpful, as it shows that even the tiniest of battles are absurdly dramatic: If you're zoomed out enough, you see two little ship icons, and perhaps some fire in between them, Zoom in more and you see stunning 3D models, complete with thrusters, blinking lights, etc, and you can see exactly what they're firing. Zoom in until one fills your screen and suddenly you notice that it's on fire, sparks are flying, and the enemy's fire is devastating the hull with massive explosions.

If you love strategy games, space games, or just want to watch ships burn, you'll probably like this game.

reviewText:
It's certainly become one of the most enjoyable Space RTS games out there, and serves as a solid RTS in general. Do be warned that the pacing is quite slow (though there are plenty of options, both during the game and in the set-up, to circumvent that) and multiplayer isn't exactly a crowning feature. The touted 4X elements are certainly more present here than they were in the vanilla game, but you'll need the moderately priced DLC to really achieve the advertised combination. Alternatively, you can use mods, which are fairly easy to install.

Also, there is no campaign, and there likely won't be one. The backstory, while interesting, is all you get. So, you'd better enjoy skirmish mode.

For those of you who owned the vanilla game (and only vanilla) this is a significant improvement, as it comes bundled with the two other expansions, Entrenchment and Diplomacy. If you owned the Trilogy edition...not so much. The core Rebellion content mainly focuses on faction diversification. There are now six total factions, consisting of two sects of each of the three vanilla factions. They play very differently, especially in the late game when their tech trees begin to diverge. The TEC Loyalists, for example, are centered around an impenetrable defense and long-range bombardment, whereas the Vasari Loyalists become extremely devoted to mobility and attritive tactics (as in, they operate without terrestrial holdings and can cannibalize conquered worlds). New means of attaining victory have been added, from Diplomatic to KotH and more. The graphics are enhanced, and two new ship classes (super-massive, incredibly powerful Titans and just-barely-larger-than-a-squadron-unit

reviewText:
This game has been adding new game objectives, research, ships, orbital structures and planet types for a number of years now and it has turned it into a really great game. Each of the races and now factions within the races (Loyalist/Rebellion) offer higher defensive, offensive, economic or boosts to your culture (culture will overthrow enemy planets non violently) which gives a varying amount of replayability and playstyles. The learning curve for playing this game is low to mid, it doesn't take long to learn how to play.

In this game you'll be able to build up a massive fleet armada or split your fleet in two or three and raid the enemy's core planets after destroying their fleet. You'll be able to build starbases that can halt the advance of armadas until they are dealt with that also protect your trade empire from pirate raiders, jumping away from a starbase before it is destroyed seriously damages ships automatically.

This recent expansion breaks each of the three races into a loyalist and rebel faction. Each group has unique researchable abilities that offer different playstyles (defensive, offensive, culture) and each loyalist and rebel race receives a different Titan ship, a juggernaught of a ship that is 10 times larger than any capitol ship. These Titans can easily throw a pitched battle by special abilities that will either do area effect or very high single target damage, while others are disablement oriented, reducing the damage your fleet takes and reducing the firing rate of the enemy.

General overview of races:

TEC (Trade Emergency Coalition) - An economic powerhouse compared to the other races with quicker access to trade ports and higher research done that gives you extra credits anytime another faction buys something. The ships they field are considerably weaker though at end game research, as they have less fleet support abilities unless you have they loyalist capitol ship in the fleet to help reduce incoming damage. Their ships have high armor and their ultimate weapon is the Novalith Cannon, a weapon that sits in a planet's gravity well and regularly fires shots at enemy planets destroying all life on them and making them temporarily uncolonizable.

Advent - This race, in my opinion, fields the best armadas in the game. Their capitol ships and cruisers offer a lot of support abilities to spread damage to each ship, redirect damage from their own ships back to the enemy, area effect shield recharge all the while fielding a massive amount of fighters and bombers making the need for direct engagement with an enemy fleet purely optional. The flip side to this is they have a really weak economy and the worst ultimate weapon compared to the TEC or Vasari. Their ships have very high shields and their ultimate weapon shoots at enemy planets your planet's culture which is easily countered.

Vasari - A brutal alien race that terrorizes the galaxy thru subjegating and enslaving other races. They get a later start with building up their economy but their economy is pretty great at end game. Their units have a variety of disablement oriented abilities and a area effect hull repair and they tend to have higher hull values than the other races. Further research into missile technology allows you to bypass shields making them excellent against advent in a stand up fight. Their ultimate weapon is the Kostura cannon that will shoot at enemy planets damaging and disabling enemy structures in that planet's gravity well. If an enemy fleet is there, the fleet will be temporarily disabled and be unable to move or attack making it an invaluable tool to use while attacking with your fleet.

If you are a RTS fan or just enjoy viewing space warfare, I'd definetely recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game.... This game is probably the best Space based game I've ever played.

Sin's of a Solar Empire started off as a revolutionary Space combat system, with hundreds of planets, dozens of ships and unlimited possibilities.

Rebellion is the next step, and Stardock did not dissapoint me at all. This game is as close to perfection as you can get. Amazing graphics, gripping storyline, and explosive combat. In this game, you take command of one of six Factions, and command an entire empire throughout war and peace. You can choose from one of six factions, of three Races.


The Trader Emergency Coalition is the human empire. They were formed after an alien assault, and have been fighting a losing battle ever since. The Loyalists want to find a diplomatic way to end the war, preferably saving as many lives as possible along the way. The Rebels on the other hand, are only interested in Human domination, and will do anything to destroy the enemies of humanity.

The Advent are a long lost sect of Humanity. They strive to seek peace and enlightenment, and the only way they see they can succeed is by either indoctrinating everyone else, or destroying those who appose the Unity. The loyalists are trying to remain peacefull, spreading their religion as far as they can, taking over worlds through persuasion, and not violence. The Rebels are violently assaulting other worlds, using massive weapons of mass destruction and mind control to overthrow planetary governments.

The Vasari are an ancient race, born in the beginnings of the galaxy. They are all that remain of a galaxy spanning empire, and are fleeing from a dangerous species, known only as the unknown. They are incredibly powerful, and will do anything they can to keep their species alive, through intimidation, or slavery. Loyalists of the Vasari commune want to enslave or destroy the other races they have encountered, while the Rebels want to work together to survive, and the gods know that to survive something that can destroy an entire empire, who knows what will have to be done.....


20/20 Score

10/10 for Graphics and Visuals
10/10 for Storyline and Gameplay

reviewText:
Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is the latest iteration of Sins of a Solar Empire, a space themed real time strategy game with a truly fantastic scale. I’ve seen battles with hundreds of ship engaging each other as more reinforcements filter in from distant star systems. Even friendly comp stomp games can last for hours as your forces slowly conquer the cosmos. Whether this is epic or tedious is a matter of taste, but I fall into the epic camp.

Sins plays a little like a 4X game. You’ll explore the universe, colonize and develop planets, research all manner of military and civilian technologies, meet other peoples, and kill them.  Throughout you’ll be struggling with issues like whether asteroid colony Y would benefit more from a refinery, trade port, or capital ship factory. You are Space Stalin, staying up late in your space Kremlin while devising plans to ensure your people are mining enough crystals to build the ships you’ve just researched. This isn’t a game where you’ll dance a little hero unit around the map. Yes, you can do a little micromanagement. However, you’ve got a lot on your plate already. It’s best to just let the Battleship Captain decide when he wants to fire his special Gauss Rail Gun.

If you want to play an RTS during a lunch break then this is definitely not for you. It’s possible that you could order units to help save an ally’s distant home world, step away from the computer, go out and grab some lunch, eat said lunch, and return before the battle finished. That kind of scale and speed will be a turn off for many people. However, I highly recommend Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion to patient people with an inner Ming the Merciless.

reviewText:
Hey all, Deadpool here with a review. Now that the obvious is out of the way, let's get to it shall we? Here be the review for Sins of a Solar Empire; Rebellion, a 4X RTS game set in space. Oooooooooo.

Plot
There isn't one. At least not that I can infer. I think. Let me start from the beginning. Rebellion is the first Sins game I have played. As with sequels, you'd usually get a recap, yes? Crysis 3 has a rather long one, the Assassin's Creed games(save for the first) have recaps, and the list goes on. Sins of a Solar Empire; Rebellion does not have one. So me being new to the series, I have absolutely no clue what is going on. The intro video, while stunning and well done, offered little to no info. All I know(and still know because I am too lazy to Google) is that there are humans, some very spiritual alien peeps, and some nano-tech alien things that are running from something. Each race has been split into Loyalists and Rebels. So you have, vaguely, six to choose from.

The Good Stuff
The game is pretty well balanced. The developers seem to have a keen eye for balance between the various ship classes and races that produce the ships. I tried spamming with smaller frigates, but was easily defeated. A balanced fleet is a good one, and the Devs seem to have hit the nail on the head when it came to making sure of it. The Same can be said for the balance between the factions themselves.

Graphics. Wow. The explosions seem legit, and make the camera shake if you zoom in. Which, I love. The level of detail in the game is astounding. Then again, it being a space based game, you'd really hope so. Truly well thought out and beautiful artwork. Same can be said for the sound. Very, very well done and aesthetically pleasing.

Complex, but simple. It is complex enough to thoroughly enjoy and really make you think about your next move, yet simple enough to where there is a minimal learning curve; especially for someone like me who has never played a Sins game before. Little to no micromanaging of your planets and/or colonies, which allows you to truly focus on your fleet, defense, economy, and of course diplomacy.

Now, for diplomacy. The devs offered up something I haven't seen in diplomacy before I played this game. It is complex with your actions affecting not only the intended faction, but rippling through to the other factions in the game. And likewise with their actions. Not only that, but to create alliances and forge pacts, not only do they have to like you, but your people have to like them. I, for one, absolutely love this. It prevents you from going all out and forging alliances just to win an allied victory and truly brings into perspective just how closely and how far the devs went to instill a balance into the game.

Voice acting. It is phenomenal. 'Nuff said. Some of the best I have seen. Or heard, rather.

Diversity. The diversity between the three races, and even their Loyalist and Rebel sub-factions, is outstanding. The research options differ greatly between the three races. The technologies are different, the voices are different, everything is different! Mostly. Each time you play as a different race, it feels and plays completely different from the last.


The Bad Stuff
Campaign. There isn't one. The only mode, aside from multiplayer online, is relative to skirmish mode on Command and Conquer games. That's it. No campaign to play through, nothing. Nothing but a repetitive procession of skirmish after skirmish. Set up, conquer, win. Set up, conquer, win. As amazing as the game looks, it gets old. Unless you're like me and use Galaxy Forge(Comes with the game, program you can use to create your own maps) to play very sadistic games with the AI.

Speaking of AI, it is very finicky. If you have great defenses, they don't attack. Even when you set them on the hardest difficulty, they wont attack. The only good thing about the AI is the diplomacy, and watching them fight between themselves. I once sat for two hours watching five AI's battle it out over 2 different star systems. There was a tug of war, take and lose. The AI's fight each other real well, but if you're too powerful they leave you alone like you have the plague. If you maintain a decent level of awesomeness, they will attack you. They will take what you have and own you. So it is somewhat of a balancing act. Depends on how you want to play it.

Micro Management. I put this in the Bad Stuff section as well because if you're like me and love micro managing, then this game will disappoint. Yeah sure you build things in orbit to advance your culture and spread it, but so what? I want to be able to see who the leaders are, select the political whatevermajiggs, change the funding from research to defense if I wanted, and truly see what my people(ingame people, you know, in my empire) are made of. But no. You get a planet, some aircraft whizzing around it, and city lights if you're on the nighttime side of it. That's it. To me, once you learn the game and how to play it, there is sooooo much room for micromanagement. But, I can see why the Devs didn't do it. It is an RTS game, and sometimes not enough time for micromanagement.


Conclusion
Now that I touched on just a few of the high and low points of the game, here is my condensed review of my review of the game. To be frank, the game is amazing. Excellent mechanics, balance, diplomacy, voice acting, visuals, diversity, and a true pleasure to play. Tutorials are available if you have questions, but in the end you will still be discovering little things here and there that you can do months after the fact. Lack of a campaign makes the endless C&C and Starcraft-like map skirmishes repetitive and give it a lack of long-term playability(Invented that word just for this review). In this game, I feel, the Pros outweigh the Cons and thus I give it a 7 out of 10.

reviewText:
This game.... This game is probably the best Space based game I've ever played.

Sin's of a Solar Empire started off as a revolutionary Space combat system, with hundreds of planets, dozens of ships and unlimited possibilities.

Rebellion is the next step, and Stardock did not dissapoint me at all. This game is as close to perfection as you can get. Amazing graphics, gripping storyline, and explosive combat. In this game, you take command of one of six Factions, and command an entire empire throughout war and peace. You can choose from one of six factions, of three Races.


The Trader Emergency Coalition is the human empire. They were formed after an alien assault, and have been fighting a losing battle ever since. The Loyalists want to find a diplomatic way to end the war, preferably saving as many lives as possible along the way. The Rebels on the other hand, are only interested in Human domination, and will do anything to destroy the enemies of humanity.

The Advent are a long lost sect of Humanity. They strive to seek peace and enlightenment, and the only way they see they can succeed is by either indoctrinating everyone else, or destroying those who appose the Unity. The loyalists are trying to remain peacefull, spreading their religion as far as they can, taking over worlds through persuasion, and not violence. The Rebels are violently assaulting other worlds, using massive weapons of mass destruction and mind control to overthrow planetary governments.

The Vasari are an ancient race, born in the beginnings of the galaxy. They are all that remain of a galaxy spanning empire, and are fleeing from a dangerous species, known only as the unknown. They are incredibly powerful, and will do anything they can to keep their species alive, through intimidation, or slavery. Loyalists of the Vasari commune want to enslave or destroy the other races they have encountered, while the Rebels want to work together to survive, and the gods know that to survive something that can destroy an entire empire, who knows what will have to be done.....


20/20 Score

10/10 for Graphics and Visuals
10/10 for Storyline and Gameplay

reviewText:
So I have hap this game for about 3 years now, and recently I told my friend about that game because it was on sale. (not this sale,but the last one.) He sees it and thinks it's amazing, I tell him that it is. He gets the game and we immediately begin playing. After about 5 hours of teaching him how to play, he gets tired and leaves.

Now a little bit ago I say we should play again, he is hesitant, but he agrees to anyway. We start up the game and I set everything to faster so he can play a quicker game (faster training, mining, culture.) Everything is going great for the first 10 minutes or so, until we establish first contact.

Now since he is still learning, I have had to teach him up to this point and our technological advancements and colonization have been slow. Not to mention I had to help him learn how to play the Advent as I was playing the TEC. I expected that star to star jumping would be reached within 10 minutes, but they are already here. A couple scouts are not really an issue, so we continue to expand, then my friend is alof a sudden really scared because he had lost one of his colonies. I simply thought he accidentally scuttled it and he was paying attention to his (small) army fighting rebels. It wasn’t until the third colony that I went to investigate. There, I found a HUGE war party in his late colony’s system.

Im freaking out and Telling him to Bring his army back to defend his home world, and that's when I notice that the same this is happening to me. With an army of that size, they must have been expanding into the other galaxies without much trouble, and now we were paying for it.

About 20 minutes later, and 20 minutes of constantly defending our colonies, I have a great idea. I immediately start rushing siege frigates and my titan (the Ragnarov titan is personally my favorite, which is basically a giant rail gun, with engines and smaller guns all around it) and I tell him to do the same. Confused, he has to listen because he has no other ideas.

My idea is to win by sneaking 100 siege frigates and a titan into the enemy territory, and take their home planet before they can gets troops back from the front lines (our colonies). And very soon, the pan is under way. We have literally every single ship, which added together is only a fraction of our enemies army, and send them on a straight shot for his home world. During this time, he has taken almost all of our colonies(be both have about 2 left) and they don’t seem to care that our armies have disappeared.

5 Minutes later, we make the final jump into a heavily fortified system with gauss platforms and mines EVERYWHERE and a fully upgraded starbase. Note that at this point, all of his ships are flying back to save his home planet, but by then it's too late. we destroy his defences and being bombing the planet. Sadly, about half way through destroying it, my friend lost his Capital, and his ships lost all ties with me, but is was too late. The final nuke was fired, sealing his fate as the first of his ships jumped into the system. We had won in probably the most dirty and underhanded way, but we had won.

10/10 would accidentally understand the plot to Ender’s Game.

reviewText: This game has been out for several years now and the fact that it still gets content upgrades (although the last few were somewhat less exciting DLCs) shows that is staying power. And honestly it's not coming from nowhere. It is probably one of the best space themed RTS games that you can get currently and the graphics, while a little dated, are still serving their purpose by giving you lots of beamy and exploding goodness when it comes to space battles. What however probably speaks the most for why this game is successfull is it's excellent user interface. All the information you require is easily accessible with the click of a button, if it's not displayed on screen right away. There is no rummaging through submenus and other distracting stuff to find out how many ressources are produced in which colony. The three different factions, which with the addon Rebellion got further split up into Loyalist and Rebel factions also provide many different approaches at how to play the game as each faction has their specialities. Want to have staunch unmoving defenders that will be even harder to remove from a system than cancer? Go with the TEC loyalists. Want a seemingly endless horde of ♥♥♥♥ cheap units to drown your enemies in AND be a pirate on top of that? Go with the TEC rebels, and that are just two sides of one race you can play.\n\nIf you want a space themed RTS with huge space battles, then this is the game to go for.

reviewText:
Your basic so-so space related tactical sim game. I bought a half dozen of similar games from Steam on sale, and while each has their good and bad points, all play basically the same with little variance and limited tactical ability. Get it on sale, not even close to being worth the full price.

Good points. Space battles aren't the quick turn based fights that many such simulators have. The battles in Rebellion actually take a while, you don't need to micromanage them.. just send your ships to enemy area, and your off, they can fight their own fights. Lets you work on your planets, research, etc while your fleet is off doing stuff. Also pirates. Most maps have a pirate homeworld that constantly spawns harder than normal pirate fleets to harass you and the npcs/other players playing the map. Sadly this is easily handled by just giving money in bounty thus letting the pirates attack someone else.

Bad points. Game is pretty easy once you figure out a few basic things. Fleet battles will determine map winner, you won't win on diplomacy, or other tactics. Biggest best fleet wins. Pirates are a pain until you quickly figure out how to post bounty switching them to other players.. easy enough. System defenses? kinda useless since fleets can just fly past your defenses unless they are specificially attacking that planet. They can just fly past your fleet until they get to the system they are targetting, so managing your fleet well = win.  Other than that, you simply do what all other space sim type games do. upgrade your planets, do research, build ships to fight other systems. But it isn't super hard, kind of boring after a while once you learn the few basic things to do (expand fast, build up fleet fast, focus more on trade/research than system defenses).

Plus there isn't any campaign. Just pick a map and play. Again, boring after you figure out how easy it is to beat opponents with a big fleet. Of all the space games, i'd say the best thing about this one is the real time fleet fighting, much better system than many of the few turn-based fighting that occurs with other games.

reviewText:
So first and foremost, I love this game, i've enjoyed it alone and even more so with friends.
For those who can't be bothered reading anything lengthy, if you are looking for a fast paced strategy game you're very much in the wrong place, go play starcraft, or, well I guess thats it (Dear god we need better RTS titles)

Rebellion takes the slow, methodical strategy of its predecessor and adds on largely to the end game but there are some new toys almost every aspect of the game. If you liked sins of a solar empire I cannot fathom any reason you wouldn't like rebellion. Havnt played either? Sins is a space based 4x Real Time Strategy game focusing quite largely on fleet composition and production with empire management taking a bit of a back seat. Don't expect civilisation depth but thats not to say its a simple game.

Rebellion in my opinion is a good game to go for as a first step into the sins series or for experienced players. The scale of the combat alone can be awesome in the literal sense of the word and the new titan class ships can make for some very interesting boss battle style engagements. The new factions (well, old factions split in to two groups) can really give players a good sense of direction and palystyle which really does run on to the rediculous once you hit the end game research.

The corvettes while were a nice addition are not overly game changing like much of the other additions much to my own dissapointment and this version still suffers from one drawback it shares with the original trilogy. The combat can look a little stupid at times. While its really cool to see the larger ships turn to fire broadsides at eachother, the smaller ships tend to just sit there like stationary platforms. The smallest ships are a little silly looking as they have a tendancy to literaly fly into their target and fire in a random direction, poorly representing any sense of speed and manuverability or even looking remotely sensible.

reviewText:
At the core of Sins of a Solar Empire is a good RTS that, with each new DLC, is becoming more and more buried under micromanaging tedium.  Truly an example of more is not better.  In my opinion, earlier versions of the game were faster, more user friendly, and more fun.  Balancing tactics and economy management is the heart of any RTS game.  The layers of complexity now in Sins just get in the way of enjoying what you are doing.

Depending on how you play, games can easily stretch beyond eight hours.  Long games can be satisfying in themselves but much of the length can be contributed to a progressive slowdown coinciding with players expanding fleets.  Even when all players running fresh hardware (that seemingly goes untaxed), in game time will stretch longer and longer.  Perhaps this can be attributed to net code and synchronizing so many thousands or individual elements.  I'm not kidding when I say I've kept a book handy to pass the time.  This slowdown, without a doubt, is the games greatest flaw.

At the end of the day, my friends and I liked Sins.  It was a fresh break from other games and we gave it over a hundred hours each on the Steam versions alone.  Worth a buy on a sale.  Just don't go for the DLC.

reviewText:
One of the greatest 4X RTS games of all time. If you like space, spaceships, epic space battles, and empire management, then this game is for you. I played the original before it was on Steam (have the retail box here) and Rebellion basically combines the basic game with all released expansions; the end result is an amazing game extended with more awesomeness.

+ The graphics are beautiful, you can freely zoom from a scale showing the entire solar system down to a single ship, the detail is amazing and space and especially the battles look incredible
+ The expansion packs have added a lot, giving more defensive options, more offensive options, and more diplomatic options
+ You can make custom maps and many maps have random elements for which planets or anomalies appear where, making for great replay value
+ Full mod support
+ The scale of this game is amazing
+ The interface holds up really well and makes managing large empires easy

- The game can be very performance demanding, especially as games drag on and everyone fields fleets of hundreds of ships, paired with hundreds of trade ships- you get the idea
- Even though diplomatic options have been expanded, it's still more action focused in general
- The three (six) factions all play fairly similar, they are about as different as Nod and GDI in C&C
- No campaign, this game is focused on skirmish matches both in Single- and Multiplayer

reviewText: Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is by far one of the best RTS games I've played, and certainly my most favorite Science fiction RTS since it came out. reviewText:
If you don't own any other version of Sins, you should get it. It's basically the stock game +4 expansion packs as a standalone, you'll not lack anything.

Sins itself is a grand scale RTS that makes running a large stellar empire surprisingly easy. The AI goes from Kitten to cheating ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ depending on the difficulty settings.

Sins is a very solid game but not without flaws.

Research, while necessary, is often not very exciting with a lot of techs upping numerical values rather then providing new toys.

Nothing looks BAD in the game, but there is a lack of details, like weapon/turret animations or visible damage which mean zooming in beyond a certain point can be disappointing.

It is a great game to do some 'comp stomp-ing' with a friend, with the AI initially proving a challenge, however once that challenge is surmounted the AI cannot sustain momentum and seems to peter out.

reviewText:
When I first bought this game the voice acting really annoyed me.  There are still elements in the voice acting I can't stand.  For example, the sound of water sucked through a straw doesn't count as good sound effects.  It just sounds dumb.  Also the sound of THE SAME voice actor over and over again for different parts, or some of the ridiculous alien monster sounds.

I hated it so much that I actually wrote a script to copy those sounds out to be replaced by sounds that were neutral.

----- ENOUGH RANTING ALREADY -----

That said, there is also some good voice acting, like I hope this isn't another suicide mission!" and when a new colony is founded "A new colony has been founded" and there's some dramatic orchestral music.  "The price on our heads has increased!"  Those I really like
date:
and the more I play the more it grows on me.


The gameplay is simplistic - all the ships do whatever it is they do
recommended:
and there are minimal choices for changing how they work.  And the capital ships have level caps (maybe that's fixed in some mods).

There are a number of mods which I still have to try.

What I like about this game: it goes pretty fast.  Unlike SotS or Star Ruler or GalCiv - this feels like it plays much faster.  Maybe I'm hallucinating too.  The tech tree is certainly much smaller than those other games - so the whole game feels smaller.

So for a "quick space game 4x" this is one I find myself going back to."

reviewText:
This game is kind of a tough call. While I do really like it, I also started getting annoyed by it very suddenly. If you play against AI, and have multiple AI, they end up ganging up on you, and not fighting eachother. Which may not be a big problem at fist glance, but then the real problem occurs. Super weapons. The AI spams them to no end. And it's incredibly frustrating after a short time. Once the game goes on for a while, you end up bogged down in a boring defend against wave after wave of enemies while rebuilding your rear planets over and over due to super weapon attacks war of attrition. And not one of material/money, but of patience.

I'd love to recomend the game because it is fun, but this fatal flaw for anyone who doesn't want to just rush every single game, leads me little choice but to vote no. Had I known of this issue before I bought the game, I wouldn't have bought it at all.

The AI issue you can fix somewhat, by locking the teams. But the super weapon issue, there is no fix for, as the mods I've found that allow them to be disabled either don't work at all, or cause the game to crash every 10 minutes or so.

If all you want to do is rush constantly, every single game, then by all means get the game. But if you prefer longer, but still winable games against 5+ AI, play something else.

reviewText:
Sins was a game that honestly had me relatively surprised in a number of aspects. Here's my thoughts:

Graphics: 7/10; For a game made more than a couple years ago, it manages to push a rather impressive resolution, detail and ambience. Everything from massive capitol ships and Titans, to small units such as fighter squadrons are well textured, clearly defined and able to give a good visual experience that's both impressive, and incredibly well optimised. So well in fact even older PC's can handle the game on higher graphics levels. Sadly in large scale games with multiple players the game does tend to putz around a bit with the number of items and commands being issued but thats simply a common feature among RTS games.

Gameplay: 8/10; RTS at its finest, with a bit of micro-RPG elements attatched to each ship, the game is fun to play, flows well, and encourages good strategy as well as economy management. The controls are a bit much to take in all at once, and it like many other games involving a 4 tier RTS, requires a bit of a learning curve. However, once understood the game is able to flow well, it rewards tactics and an understanding of your opponent, and a satisfying feeling of accomplishment.

Sound: 5/10; Its an older game, but the sound effects hold up, and are fairly solid. Listening in on battles is an enjoyable experience and the sound levels are accurate. However some of the more notable abilities used by the Titan units seem unnessecarrily loud, and if listening with headphones can be somewhat deafening if zoomed in close to observe the battle.

Addictiveness and Depth: 4/10; The game suffers from one major flaw. Its absolute lack of a single player campaign. The game has all the makings of what could be a very entertaining single player space domination game, however it is restricted to arena style RTS combat over a set number of worlds against 1 - 7 opponents. The game does have an interactive level up system for Capitol ships, which are allowed to level in a manner you can guide them in by increasing their abilities, and the games heavy amount of depth via a diplomacy system, a working active and live economy, as well as player issued missions, falls by the wayside when faced with the knowledge that the entire games structure is simply a Starship based battle arena.

Overall: 6/10; The games very fun if you can settle into its niche setting. Enjoying well detailed space battles happening in real time is difficult to manage especially with the graphical quality this game manages to provide. However the lack of a single player campaign hits this game hard, and pushes it onto a back burner if you're looking to pick it up. Best to get if you know a friend that plays it as well, or if you enjoy the competition of facing down another player in a 3 Tier RTS game. Only reason this game isnt being reccomended is its heavy reliance on other players for any sort of content.

Well, I'm reviewing now.

For the amount fo time I have played and already getting bored, I must say that as of Feb. 1, 2016, this game is NOT worth $40.

reviewText: Where can I even start with this game.......so put yourself in my shoes. A veteran total war player looking to find new RTS games to get away from the dying series that I spent years getting good at. Leaving behind, my friends I'd made, and achievements, to find a new, and refreshing game to take my mind off, if even in a small way. Upon my travels, I venture upon this game......the artwork looks cool, the screenshots look amazing, the description looks epic........but then my eyes wander down to the price tag. For the rather steep price of 39.99.....I can be a galactic tyrant vying for control of the galaxy. I think long and hard on the issue......do I really wanna go back to total war? After some thought, I decide to take a chance....I pay up, and to my hardrive, this magnificant software is installed. I enter the game, and instantly I see promise with a great sound track and breathtaking visuals. I feel so humbled by the new game that has surrounded me in it's atmosphere, and I meekly wander over to the tutorials, where I learn the way of the galactic conquerer. Then I start up a real game, and after only a few adreneline soaked engagements, I am thrilled to know that my money was spent wisely and have no regrets on the risk that I took to experience this game. Ever since that fateful day, this game has been my therepist.....calming my mind with it's awesome gameplay whenever I am stressed. I love this game and have no doubt that anyone with the slightest fanboyism for sci fi and strategy will love this too. I highly recommend this game if you are looking at it's page, wondering the same way I wondered whether or not to take that risk.

reviewText:
Bottome line up front: 8.5/10 game, tons of fun. However I do not recommend purchasing Sins on Steam. The Steam verison is buggy and crashes randomly. Purchase Sins from another third-party vendor, or directly from the developer / publisher.


I came across Sins while I was deployed to the middle east, a buddy of mine gave me a pirated copy. I immensely enjoy this game, and I put countless hours into it when I was off-duty. If I had to guess I'd say I played around 8-900 hours over 9 months.

I never had any problems with the game, except for the mulitplayer not working due to it being a pirated copy. It crashed around 7-8 times over 9 months, and most of those were when I was intentionally pushing the game and my computer to their limits. Whether it was single player, LAN, small pre-made maps or huge custom ones, the game worked as it should. I would notice some issues with frame rate late-game, when there would be hundreds of ships on the screen during battles, but that's likely my computer reaching it's upper limits and not any issue with the game engine.

I recently decided to buy Sins in order to support the developers for making a game I have so thoroughly enjoyed. I Downloaded and installed the game, launched it, and the steam bootstrapper kept crashing and rebooting. I didn't restart my computer before attempting to launch the game, and yes I know you should, but I've never had a problem with running a steam game after installing it without restarting. That was the first sign of something being wrong.

I restarted, and that fixed the issue. I get into my first match, a 1v1 on the Gemini medium map, and the game randomly crashes around 20 minutes in. I relaunched and got into another game, this time a 2v2v2 on a huge multi star comp map, and it crashed again at around 90 minutes.

I can count on my hands how many times the pirated copy crashed, over the hundreds of matches I played. The official copy of the game from steam crashed twice in a row in the first two matches. And I bet you my next paycheck it will crash again the next match I play.

A pirated copy of the game is more stable than the steam release. Absolutely pathetic, Valve.

Edit: I have since played 6 more matches, two of which crashed. So Steam Sins is 4 for 8, or 50% failure rate. Going to try reinstalling to see if that fixes the issue for me. Revised some portions of this review, as I wrote this while slightly intoxicated.

reviewText:
A great RTS for space lovers. Keeps the game play relitivly simple while not feeling boring. If you liked the previous games, you will love this one. If you havent played the previous games, you like space, and like RTS, then check this out.

Great blend of resorce managment, building an army, and expansion gameplay. Large space battles are a regular event in this game, where hundreds of ships clash in epic battles over planets. For those who love to just brute force, you will enjoy that part.

For those who enjoy more subtle gameplay, the diplomacy and civilian trees offer that. Spread your culture to your enemys worlds and eventually spark a rebellion on that planet, making it ripe for you to come in and colonise it. Ally yourself with those close to you and trade resorces and tech to enhance your own abilities. Or go it alone and give missions to the pirates to have them assault your enemys.

No matter how you want to play this game, you can find a way to win that is challanging and satisfying. With the 3 default races, and the 2 factions in each, you can find a race and faction that fits your play style.

reviewText:
In addition to pruchasing a crappy game (thankfull on sale), I learned how short the Steam Refund time frame is [2hrs only - about twice the length of the tutorials in this game...]

The game has great graphics... that you will never see.
If you are engaged in a space battle, and want to get an overview of what is going on you will be zoomed way out. In fact 90% of the time this game is played so far away from the ships and orbitals that all you will see are nice outlines of them highlighted in space. Hooray, wasted graphics.

Game play is not really fun either. You spend a significant amount of time just waiting for your ship to move. They take forever to turn and to jump from system to system. The battles look rather impressive with all the shots and lasers, but they are slow and boring... Shields constantly regen, and everything has tons of health... so it takes forever to kill even light frigates.

I was hoiping for more 4x and less RTS. I got mostly RTS with a tiny bit of 4x.

Not what I wanted.

reviewText:
Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is in its core a Command & Conquer type RTS in space with light 4x elements
4x FeaturesLet's start with the 4x elements first. There is almost no planetary development. You can grow population, add some slots for buildings, improve your planet's health all with a couple of clicks. It will take a few minutes to fully develope your planet.

The research tree is generic. When you build let's say a frigate factory you will unlock one ship type. There is a research tab for every ship in the game for unlock only purpose.  There are 4 tabs alone for upgrading armor, doing the same thing for every tab. Same thing for laser weapons, 3 tabs where every tab is divided into 2 levels ( need to research 1 tab twice) for every incremental increase in laser damage. There is so much unnecessary stuff in the tree that it is just not tech tree worthy as a whole.

Expansion is pretty straightforward take a planet by force or take it over by influence. Panets are connected by phase lanes (strings) over which are you able to move and spread your influence. I'd say diplomacy is the only 4x worthy element this game has to offer and worked out well. You can accept missions to increase their relation with you or you give them a mission to improve your relation with them. If the relation in both ways is high enough the chance of them accepting heavier stuff is more probable.

You may ask (missions) a faction to destroy ships, capital ships, structures etc and the amount of it. If they kill 5 or 15 enemy ships for you depends on the relationship. You are also able to join pacts. The better the relation, the more pacts you can join like cease fire, peace, vision or trade treaties. Managing your economy is just as thin as in any other RTS, colonize asteroids for metal and crystal income and max out your population for credits.

RTS based gameplayFirst of all there is no singleplayer campaign, it is just pure skirmish against bots and multiplayer. Second point I want to make is that the majority of your game time is spend by battling enemy fleets. Gameplay wise you build up a fleet of mixed unit types. Attack the enemy, lose a big chunk of your fleet, rebuild your fleet and go for the next planet. Flanking does not pay off. There isn't any tactics involved other than timing the activation of your ship's special abilities.

There is no stealth, no surgical strikes, no flanking. Every game plays out the same, build a big balanced fleet and overwhelm the enemy. Quick building is your way to succes. This is a casual RTS game with extra bells and whistles (4x elements) which lacks strategic depth. The game has good graphics and the battles are nice to see when you are zoomed in, which rarely happens anyway. I did not expect this game to have such a lack of tactical gameplay, such a shame.

For a casual RTS experience this game is good. Good graphics, flashy space battles, lots of cool units, wonderful sound effects, always things to do, mods and the 4x elements , altough very minor, are a plus. I would not buy the game if you expect a 4x game, total war style of gameplay or the ability to use tactics to decide battles. I would only recommend this game if you want another casual RTS experience (with casual I don't mean quality, but there are more of them on the market in terms of gameplay). I will give this game thumbs down however (has nothing to do with rating but with recommendation), the reason for downvoting is the lack of depth gameplay wise and the bells an whistles don't make up for it.

reviewText:
While games like Company of Heroes lie in the fast paced end of the RTS spectrum, Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion is occupying the other end. This game is a slow ordeal and a simple 1 v 1 match can take up to 3 hours of your time, if not more, but that's where the game strenghts lie.

Sins is not meant to be a game where you're sitting at the edge of your seat, it's a game about tactically colonizing planets and researching skills, abilities and constructions that suit your playing style.

If you want a RTS to relax to and feel extremely rewarded by, then I heartily recommend Sins, if you're unsure, then go watch some gameplay from the game, if you find the video boring, then chances are that you'll find the game boring as well.
